reviewText:
Early Access Review

I think I can speak for everyone when I say that we gamers have always wanted something as amazing as this.  Hands down, BEST dino simulation game I have ever played.   It might not be complete, but that doesn't make it any less amazing.  The graphics are perfect, the animations are perfect, and the fact that you get to play with other people world-wide instead of NPC's makes the game that much more fun.

You can create herds and migrate around massive maps just like the real dinos would, and defend each other from predators that wanna' snack on you.  Personaly I love the satasfaction of smashing a T-Rex into the ground as a Triceratops.

You can form packs as predators to become stronger in order to take down tough prey, by using tactics that any natural pack predators would use.  Circle the prey, then go for the kill once it's confused and can't react quick enough.

In my opinion, the creators of this game deserve every penny for this game.  I can only imagine how much more amazing it will be once it's complete.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let me start of by saying the concept is one I've been waiting for ever since the inital boom of zombie survival games, so much so that I purchased the game as more to back the idea than the game itself.

Currently the game is not a game at all, in the sence that their is no progression or gameplay of note that would have you login on a daily/weekly basis. Currently Dino's spawn in and have the ability to eat and drink pressing E, to run holding shift and jump (if they are able to jump) by pressing space bar. Their only perceivable objective is to eat, drink and fight other dino.

Simple right and left click attacks means combat currently is a circle strafe button bash until someone falls over or runs away, its clumsy and somthing I hope they will improve on heavily if this game is going to reach its full potential. Stealth mechanics, element of suprise, persistant injuries from battle. These are some of the things I would like to see implemented, only time will tell.

The maps are also apaulling, a big draw to a game like this will be exploration. The current maps are terrible and make the whole game feel rushed. The Dino skins themselves are awsome, however they are been taken from a previous project known as the stomping grounds so really what we have to see for our investment so far is the menu/server listings and the maps which are sub-standard even for EA at this point in time.

Looking forward. If they implement some of the aspects of the game they have stated this might turn out to be an amazing game. As it stands right now, its little more than an engine you can spawn some dino entites in. I'll be keeping an eye on the project and I will be updating this review with my own experiances as and when updates happen.

Currently I would recommend you do not purchase the game unless you want to invest into the ideas and concepts of what this game COULD become in a year from now.

They have said that they will add more intresting stuff, like Quetzalcoatlus which is a giant flying reptile and other stuff, so I suggest you pick this up later when it becomes more finished and more known, and I will do the same, I got a refund for this game and chances are, I will buy it again in the future, there is brilliant stuff in here and lots of potential, just not now though which sucks because I want to love this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has a lot of potential. Even though it's in early access at the moment, the dinosaur models look great and the different skins/textures look amazing on them. The animations are fluid, the controls are simple and work well. The only thing lacking at the moment is actual content, but that is to be expected since this game is in a very early Alpha stage. The only thing you can do as of now is select a dinosaur (which is limited to only 4 types at the moment), explore the island (which is ENORMOUS) and hunt other dinos (depending on whether you're a carnivore or not). And even though some people may think that an enormous map is great, it becomes null and void when it's completely empty and you can't find any other players. With no mini-map system in place, you'll find yourself aimlessly wandering around the massive world with nothing to do and no one to interact with. But I will admit that on the rare occasion that you DO find another dinosaur, it feels pretty awesome to fight them or just hang out with them and form your own herd.

My final input will be this: if you're looking for a polished game right off the bat, you're going to be disappointed if you buy it now. While I don't regret my purchase, I suggest that any potential buyers out there wait for a more updated version before getting this game, because with the state it's in, I think a more reasonable asking price would be around $10-$12. But if the developers hold their own in the end and release the final game with all of the features that they promised, then it will definitely be worth the $21.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you like the choice to be a dinosaur, or human and survival, look no further than The Isle. This game is still in early development, so a player only has the ability to play a herbivore or carnivore, for now. In the future, they are going to add playable humans (cannibals, tribals, mercernaries, etc.)

When you start out in the game, you have the ability to pick the species of dinosaur you want to play. The choices are Austroraptor, Carnotaurus, Tyrannosaurus, Allosaurus, and Suchomimus for carnivores, while the herbivores get the choices of Dryosaurus, Maiasaura, Triceratops, Puertasaurus, Shantungosaurus, Anklyosaurus, Gallimimus, and Diabloceratops. Your main goal for now is to survive. When you start the game, your food and water will be around half, while your stamina is full.

When I started the game, it took a little get used to manuevering my way around the map. Coordinates and landmarks are useful, when you have a certain destination to get to. The players in species chat, I find, can also be very helpful, when trying to find my way around in the game. At first, I played a Raptor, then dabbled a bit with Dryo... now my main dinosaur characters tend to be the Austroraptor and Allosaurus.

When getting more involved with the game, I find that some players of other species play fairly, while others will either kill on site, or kill for the hell of it. It is just like any other survival game, where some players tend to be kind, while others like to troll and cause havoc on the servers. As long as player finds a good group of people to play with, a player should be able to survive pretty well in the game.

Now, when playing the game, expect there to be some server crashes and restarts. They do tend to happen, and it does get frustrating at times. Some days are worse than other days, but playing the game, I find it worth it to deal with the crashes. After all, this game is still in development, so it is nothing unheard of.

Would I recommend the game in its current state? Well, if you want to experience surviving as a dinosaur, and don't mind the crashing, then yes. This game can be very fun to play, especially with a group of people. If you want to wait until the game is further developed, then that is fine too. I would recommend for a person (if they do not wish to spend the money for the game at this time), to at least have the game on their watch list. I have a good feeling about this game getting better, with progress from the developments, and there are new dinosaurs being added with the updates.

Now considering that the game is still in very Early Access don't expect it to be bug free with loads of content. Now I won't delve too far into the gameplay so much as you can get that information in other reviews, I'm just giving my impressions of the game. Also, to you Mac/Linux players out there, the dev team has not forsaken you (actually us, i play mac xD) Mac/Linux support has been added but still needs to be polished. If you want to play but don't want terrible fps/lag or bugs you may want to wait a few weeks. That being said, the game in its current bare-bones state is still very enjoyable.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is the best dinosaur survival game I've ever played. Heck, it currently feels a lot like playing a dinosaur life simulator(just without breeding and diseases). Sure it's lacking a bit of the end game content, but the devs did a great job with what they have now for us.
All the dinos are enjoyable to play, especially the herbivores. The rush of running with your gallimimus flock through the island, using the herding instinct to outwit raptors and rexes, the teamwork of shangtungs to ward off a pack of carnos, it's all awesome. When I first bought this game I expected a trex blood bath all over the island, but instead I find myself playing gallimimus the whole time and witnessed players herding as herbivores more than killing as carnivores. Also,in the long run, learning about these carnivores and how they hunted may help a new player to this game. I've seen only a couple of carnivore players actually ambush.

But anyway, though you'd need a good graphics card to play lag free, it's moderately optimized for its first release. The enviroment is extremely beautiful, I always gotta squint at the sunsets because it tricks my eyes into believing it's real. The island is very much big enough for a server of 100. I've been on a server of 60 and only ran into a few players (some not so friendly)

This game only needs to fix a couple of bugs, do something about raptors infintely clinging, upgrade the AI, and optimize, then I'm down with whatever the devs dish out for us in the future.

I can see this game going places. I always saw Stomping Land as my all time favorite Early Access game, but this replaces it for me

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hello everyone TwoPercentSkimm here!

I've been playing an aweful lot of The Isle recently and even uploading some of the gameplay on to my channel with geat results!

In The Isle you get the pleasure of choosing from a large range of dinosaurs both tall and small and all walks inbetween.   The movement feels real and weighty, even to the point that I begin to think I may actually be a dino myself (only a slight exaggeration).  The raptors are fast and sneaky, the Trex are stompy and strong, the Triceratops runs like a boss and eats trees in one mighty bite!  I can hardly explain how great it feels when you pounce on a Trex and shred them apart as a raptor before running to cover.

The devs make improvements several times a week and the dinosaurs are releasing faster than I could have ever hoped.  I recommend this game on my YouTube channel all the time and plan to cover it for a long time to come.  It feels real solid and is already a very fun game considering how much futher they plan to take it.  I honestly believe this will be the next big Dino title and I'm glad to be a part of it!

Highly Recommend!

- TwoPercentSkimm

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's really fun to be a dinosaur.
This game shows a lot of promise, but as it is, there isn't a whole lot to do yet.  The maps are huge and unless you've spent a ton of time in them you won't really know what to do or where to go. Even on a full server with 60 people you'll be hard-pressed to actually run into any other people/dinosaurs.
What this game needs is prey. It's fun to be a dinosaur and try to kill other dinosaurs. If you're a long-neck, killing just about anything becomes yay easier, and it should be that way, there's a distinct advantage these animals had back in the day to compensate for their enormous size. BUT, to make this a game and not just a dinosaur walking simulator, the maps should be filled with various NPCs to eat/hunt down.
All that said, the devs are updating the game pretty much every day, which does make a difference and shows great promise for the future of this title.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Isle shows real promise. As of right now, the features are limited and there is still a lot of refinement to be done, but it is in early Alpha, so that is to be expected. If The Isle makes it out of Alpha and the developers are able to fulfill their promises it will be a unique and amazing survival game, loaded with features, pitting Dinos vs. Humans vs. Crazy Humans.... and each other. If you want to buy a game that will really entertain you today, I would hold out untill The Isle is more developed; however if you want to make a long term investment and save a little money, buy it now while it is still cheap.

Pros:
*You play as a freaking Dinosaur!
*Most of the animations are really smooth and life like.
*You are a Dinosaur!
*The Textures and models for the Dinosaurs, and some of the terrain, are really good.
*Dinosaurs!
*For me, the game ran smooth, never droping below 30 fps.
*The promise of many new features incuding but not limited to: other factions, a vehicle system, base capturing, crafting, and MORE DINOSAURS!
*Did I mention the dinosaurs?

Disclaimer: Most if not all my cons should be fixed by release, it is only in Alpha.

Cons:
*Not much to do right now other than hunt, eat, drink, talk to other players. (Actually I think that is all you can do right now)
*The hit boxes are a bit off, and/or there is some lagg.
*The jumping animations for the smaller Dinosaurs don't transition well from a walking or standing position.
*The textures for the trees and plants are pretty bad right now. Also, the normal map for mud is funky, making it as reflective as a mirror at times.
*The load distance could be better.
*The AI for the NPC dinosarus is probably the same AI that they used for the plants.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After extensive play, I need to actually change my review and recommendation.  I'm going to do my best to keep my personal preferences from coloring my review and focus strictly on my observations and best hypotheses from a businessperson's point of view.

I'll include the caveat that I still enjoy playing this game from time to time, and in earlier iterations I absolutely loved it.  However, after learning more about the game, interacting with the community and seeing some of the developmental decisions being made, I have to safely say that I no longer recommend this game.  Here's why.

First, the development team.  While some of them are professional, I've found that this isn't the case for all of them.  I haven't had poor interactions with them personally, but I've seen them first-hand openly attack players for asking simple, reasonable questions, and they are generally rude.  They also appear to be unwilling to listen to suggestions from the community.  Unfortunately, this doesn't bode well for the future of the game, as this will negatively affect consumers' view.

Second is the fact that the public branch of the game is now the test version.  While I agree that this is a great way to obtain raw data for future improvements, I have a feeling it's going to turn away a large quantity of new players and veteran players alike.  The version out now is just too unstable and unbalanced to be enjoyable anymore.  Whereas I used to play hours each day, I maybe log in once a day or not at all - it's simply too frustrating and you are essentially forced into playing only about three dinosaurs of the choices that are available. Yes, I am aware that this is an Early Access game and bugs of all shapes and sizes are expected, but the game is almost downright unplayable (i.e. herbivores can't even eat on the most common map, and therefore can't heal or slowly starve to death) - I find the Early Access" argument to not have much teeth in this case.

Third is the direction the game is heading.  Yes
date: it's essentially a super-hardcore survival game with only a small core audience in mind - that's what the developers want to do
recommended: which is their right.  But I have a very hard time seeing the long-term financial viability of this game with what they have in mind.  I understand they want to cater to only the hardest of the hardcore
hoursPlayed: but ultimately
voteText: the end product stands to be too complex and difficult for most people to want to play.  My prediction is that it will not be profitable.\n\nThese are just my two cents.  While it is a beautiful game with a lot of potential
helpfulPercent: my outlook for this game is rather bleak based on its current state."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

One of the better dinosaur simulators I have played. I saw minor bits of gameplay and decided to try it out. Im basing this review around a couple of key factors that as a game designer, I believe are some of the more important aspects to what makes a game good or bad. Models, audio, environment, gameplay mechanics and stability. Because this game is still in early access, many of this may change, this review is more to inform on if it is worth your $20 or not.

We will start with environment:
It has a good balance of open fields and forests. It allows for good ambush play, open field battles, large herd migrations and an overall natural feel for the game. The island is massive and one can easily get lost which I love and hate at the same time. It actually makes you nervous. The actual models and textures are ok. It could benefit some better diversity in plant life. Again it is a early access build, keep that in mind. I also understand the keeping the environment tame while testing and building as it can kill a game if it goes overboard too fast. so for environment: 6/10

Audio:
This is one of my favorite parts. The audio sounds like they hired the audio team from the Jurassic park movies as the cries are incredible. The audio location is fantastic and something I hope they continue to perfect. Hearing a sound to a side of you, thats where it is. It is incredibly well done. Each dinosaur has multiple cries for varied situations, hostile, peaceful, regular, cries for help, its fantastic. For audio: 9/10

Models:
First off, lets get past the realistic and accuracy part of things. Yes these dinos arnt as feathery as they should be, but that is an extremely easy fix. I still really love these models. I am a huge fan of the Jurassic park movies, the Walking with Dinosaurs series and so on, and these models are so accurate(minus the feathers on some), detailed and beautiful. My all time favorite thus far is the Allosaur. The one skin looks as tho it was pulled straight from the second episode of Walking with Dinosaurs and I love it!!! I strongly believe that the quality for the models will continue to go this strong for future dinos and Im extremely happy about that. I would love to see alternate skins for each so people can choose the feather or non feather version. Would add even more fun. Models: 8/10

Mechanics:
It plays good. Slow dinosaurs feel slow, fast dinosaur feel fast. The controls are easy to pick up and master in no time. The attack animations and eating could have a little more feeling to them but once again easy fix and most likely will get polished as time goes on. It could do with just some more polishing and to make some of the movements smoother and a little less jerky, but its on a track! Mechanics: 7/10


Stability:
This one is the only big gripe I have thus far. Server crashes. Its rough and some days can be infuriating. And other times there are no crashes for hours. There are still bugs that pop up, clipping through the world with the camera, and some silliness with disappearing dinosaurs. I hope the devs are listening to the community and I believe they are as they are constantly updating and refining. Frame rate has been good. I have had a very consistent frame rate while playing and it doesnt just drop fro no apparent reason.  These are all temporary so keep that in mind. So if you run into any shenanigans, please inform the devs so we can attempt and make this game as fantastic as it can become! Stability: 4/10

Final thoughts:
I cannot wait for what this game will become! It plays well, its fun and just awesome to play as some of your favorite dinosaurs. I am really hoping they add plenty more species and types of dinos! I cant wait to see and play as my all time favorite, the Parasaurolophus!!! My biggest fear is with the addition of humans as I am afraid humans might be extremely over powered and I hope the devs find a really good balance, which with how they have balanced the dinos thus far, seems that they will find a sweet spot. Overall it is a great game! A must own and support if you are a fan of dinos like I am. Get a friend too and for your little Allo pack for hunting.

I highly recommend this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

OH MY GOD THIS GAME IS GOOD. At least, in its current state. Please keep reading before buying.

8/10. This is a great survival game. And it has dinosaurs!


This game offers three carnivore species and three herbivore species to play, and some truly massive maps. Admittedly, there are bugs, but for the most part it's very well-put together for an early access game. Aside from the currently defenseless and slow sauropod species, it seems people are opting to play as all five other species in roughly even numbers, which I haven't seen in other survival games that offer this option. (One example is the obscure Lif series of two games, which are a terribly broken mess of rampant killing.) The models were purchased from failed Ark: Survival Evolved ancenstor, The Stomping Land, and they look brilliant. Absolutely brilliant! The skins are also great, but don't take my word for it. Look at the screenshots!

My only concern for this game is its future. Just read what the devs plan to add. Humans? Crafting? Dinosaur catching/taming? Brutal difficulty? Yeah, there's a reason I mentioned Ark: Survival Evolved earlier. No thank you, developers! You're talented people to have put out what you have already, but this is a niche of games already well-populated! Meanwhile you've already drawn much praise for what you have out right now. Perhaps your skills are best suited to The Isle, not Primal Carnage or Ark: Survival Evolved.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Isle. Ah, what can i say about the isle?


The Isle is an extremely early access game, which seems to be pretty obvious, due to it being plastered on the front of it. Playing as a dinosaur is admittedly very fun, and i feel like many people overrate the game due to that fact. So i will be rather harsh on it in my review:

The game has absolutely ZERO content. While i can say that it's fun for a dinosaur lover like myself, as an open world dinosaur game has been one of my largest dreams, (didn't much like the primal carnage jist of things) for a non dinosaur game lover, this game could be severely dissapointing. It has six dinosaur classes. There are a few notable ones that stand out to me.


At the moment, T-rex is the most disturbingly powerful, and can kill pretty much anything. Any more than a pair of t-rexes is just outright unfair. If this game has any hope of being balanced, the nerf hammer will surely strike t-rex.


In the current stage of the game, Gallimimus is decently in the overpowered realm. It has nigh infinite sprint, making walking a passtime, since it can run for pretty much ever. It is an herbivore, which means it can eat plants and drink water, making it able to sustain itself without putting itself in harms way. With the ability to outrun ANY ingame creature, and the ability to sustain itself without ever coming into contact with a predator, it is very easy to play. Its only downside is that it has the least health of anything in the game, but that doesn't matter when nothing can catch you.


Shantungosaurus falls into the realm of underpower, in my opinion. A few classes, T-rex and Carnotaurus (I will speak of carnotaurus later) can easily dispatch a single Shantungosaurus without much of a difficulty, however, the latter of the two might have a challenge if they aren't experienced. It is a large herbivore that looks similar to an Iguanodon. As of right now, it has zero defence from a T-rex, as it is slower and less physically capable of dealing with one than vice versa. The only way to defend itself is a herd, but seeing as T-rex is often a more popular dinosaur, (Which ironically usually leads to there being more carnivores than herbivores) It will often be outnumbered anyway.





Carnotaurus, for one, falls into the balanced realm, in my opinion. It is a capable fighter, yet cannot deal with herds of herbivores, even if it has a pack itself. (Unless the herbivores are extremely outnumbered) This, i feel, is how all carnivores should be, just in different segments of the food chain. It can kill the herbivore classes if they are alone, and, even a lone T-rex if the Carnotaurus is sufficiently skilled.


Austroraptor may fall into neutral or overpowered realms after it receives its pounce back, but as of the current state, you'd be better off playing as a puddle of water. Before, it required its pounce to do pretty much any amount of damage to anything other than other Raptors and Gallimimus. Now, with its pounce currently in the process of being fixed, i cannot see anyone sane playing it and expecting to have a fair chance. For now, this class is SEVERELY underpowered, and beyond functionality.


Peurtasaurus falls into the realm of SEVERELY UNDERPOWERED. It can do NO damage, and although it has ALOT of health, it is very SLOW. It is what some people may refer to as Longnecks, (this makes me very angry, as i am a dinonerd) And what more seasoned players refer to as Peurtasaurus, its' proper name. Right now, as it can do no damage, it is a matter of time before you succumb to an angry T-rex. I hear it is getting fixed, and as little as less than 24 hours after this review goes up, however. Perhaps when it is fixed again, it may be a balanced class.


The Isle is probably wonderful upon first inspection, but it quickly becomes BORING, TEDIOUS, and a CHORE, if you find yourself in the wrong server at the wrong time, just trying to have fun. The game could be much better. but, it is surprisingly sufficient for EARLY ALPHA ACCESS. Don't buy it if you're not a dino nerd. Yet.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is amazing. It's a simple yet unique concept that should have been used LONG ago, but never was. Ever since I was little I loved dinosaurs, and wished for a game like this. Finally, the game of my dreams is here. I can play as seven creatures without limitation. Most animal simulating games require you to reach a certain level or have so many kills, or points, to advance to the next creature. Here I can be whichever creature I want. The graphics are amazing. The textures, the way the sun hits the ground, everything besides the water, which you can walk under. Beware the water, a T-Rex jumped out of it and attacked me once! This game is hardcore- there are no health bars, no hunger bars, no thirst. You can view your stamina and co-oords when you hit 'Insert', but that's all. An easy way to tell if your being attacked is if a dinosaur is chasing you and biting you or a little bit of blood appears on the screen. Once you die, a screen pops up announcing that your dead. This scared me at first, so make sure you're prepared. This is also a multiplayer game, and the comunnity is fantastic and kind. I would suggest finding a herd as soon as possible and watch out for carnos- once they spot you, there's no escape unless their stamina runs low. It would be nice if a scent button were added, so you could find a herd, find prey, or find predators and hide. I would also like the NPCs to act a bit more lifelike. This game is awesome, don't hesitate to buy it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Isle is not what I expected when I bought it. I couldn't have guessed how in depth this game was. And the kicker is it's so simple as of now.

There's no weapons or ammo or reloading or talking sh** to the other team. In fact, you can only chat with other people playing your same species. You can't hold grudges on other players because you usually can't identify them unless you're in a pack/herd.

The focus is all on survival. You have claws or spikes or teeth or size, but your best survival tool is the sounds you can make. There are 4 sounds, as well as the sounds of your attacks, that you can use to communicate and body gesture. It is very intuitive, you can understand people's intentions and what they mean even if you can't chat with them. You can threaten, call for help, roar over a great distance, and signal for peace. And it all is sewn seamlessly into a beautiful landscape and soundscape.

The devs are very active and in tune with the community, I hang out on their Discord they made for the public. There have several updates in the short time I've had this game. I've met a good bunch from the community.

TL;DR spend the 20 bucks. it keeps getting better and it's hard f'n core

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As far as the game goes, it's VERY early in development.

Honestly, in the game's current state it is NOT worth almost 20 dollars. (I got this game on sale for $16.99, it's still not worth that in my own opinion, least not this early in development.)

What you get from buying this game:

Play as a dinosuar, you have a few different types to choose from, like a T-Rex, a raptor-bird-thing, a Long Neck Mc.Stompsalot, a dinosuar that looks like Satan's pet, etc.

Two maps: Either a mesa area with many lakes everywhere or a jungle type map. (Both maps ar pretty bland with no real change in scenery no matter where you go around the map. Just... rocks n' crap. Nothing of great interest.)

A f**kng headache, due to all the weeaboo roleplayers on the servers. (By the way, there are only like 7 servers, people mostly only go to two of them, and the servers are laggy as all hell.)

There isn't really much to do in the game. You are supposed to run around and eat other dinosuars or plants, depending on whether you are an herbavore or a carnivore, but that's about it. More than half the time you'll have little 12 year olds asking you to join their herd or to do some dumb roleplay sh*t.

Do yourselves a favor and save your money.

Wait until the game is developed more.

Peace.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Take note: This review will be updated as the game grows.

The Isle in its current state is barebones. That's normal; It's in Early Access. However, the key difference between The Isle and other such barebones Early Access titles is that The Isle manages to be entertaining in a quasi-fetal stage of development.

If you don't know what that means, let me make it clear. The Isle's foundation is SOLID, and while there's bugs needing some ironing out, as well as some polish to be made, it doesn't make me worry for the game's future.

So what is The Isle anyway? RIGHT NOW, it's a dinosaur survival game. No humans. Just Dinosaurs. On a massive Island. The island itself is a bit overwhelmingly large, actually, but hopping into a server which has over thirty players makes it feel like a real world. You won't encounter people constantly, and when you do, the decisions you make will make the difference between survival and death. You can't trust anyone openly, and so you must analyse visual cues, or send some yourself. I'm told the dinosaurs will eventually have different calls to communicate, but in the mean time, interpret carefully. Even your own species could turn on you, especially if you're competing for food.

But all species tend to be played similarly to one another, as if the players have an unspoken agreement; Rexes will be cautious, but might form alliances with one another, or fight for territory, or straight up avoid each other. Raptors rarely ever resort to cannibalism, often barking a few times as a greeting, and then group up to take down the larger prey. Carnotaurus are a bit wishy-washy, and are often seen travelling alone, respecting boundaries. The herbivores will flock up together for better chances of survival, forming intimidating herds.

It's a beautiful ecosystem.

There's a steady barrage of updates getting thrown at the game with comprehensive changelogs, and they contain concrete changes and fixes, no frivolous crap.

If The Isle can keep me entertained for hours in its current state, I cannot wait to see the other factions added in, and all of the features that are already being worked on.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nGame is fun but has a long way to go, stability sucks even for early access. Bearing in mind that this is in early development I would reccommend it but there are very serious issues with the servers. You WILL get repeatedly bounced out of the servers when they have an error no matter what, collision needs to be added as well, certain dinos have too much attack radius while others cant bite a sauropod right in front of them. Virtually impossible to get certain herbos to eat. Also freezes up alot. So seeing as its early access I do reccommend it as the premise is fun but needs alot to complete. Certain things that would make it more fun would be aloowing raptors to grapple on the back of prey they pounce on an accessible HUD display and more features focused around forming and maintaining pack dynamics. Also could use a minimap as right now Cords dont work on every computer and you really have no way to tell where you're going.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFun and simple survival dinosaur game. I love playing as a dinosaur! Right now, the game is pretty bare bones, being in alpha right now, so we are basically testing the adult dinosaur gameplay. Log in to a server, pick out a dinosaur you want to play as, herbavore or carnivore, then enter a beautiful sle environment. Seek out a herd of your own kind as a herbivore, or hunt down vulnerable dinos as a carnivore. So far, eating, drinking and defending myself from those crazy carnos has yet to get old. Can't wait for the full game with races of humans, and trying to survive as a dinosaur startingfrom just a little baby!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Excerpt: A f*****g gem amongst all the cash grab of early access games.

Cons:
-Price tag is steep for an E.A. game at this point especially
-Still buggy (random disconnects, hit boxes, no syncing with other players, landscape, animation glitches
-Connecting can be a pain
-Not a lot of things to do outside of player interaction
-Player interaction as of now includes running if you eat plants, chasing people if you eat meat, and stomping on little guys.

Pros:
-Dinosaurs on a map that is one of the largest I have seen in years.

-There is NO better dinosaur/player interaction out there as of now.

-The movement of the dinosaurs, turning, roaring and running is excellent.

-Hearing roars off in the distance is one of the coolest features.

-The sounds of running herds or larger beasts approaching you is truly frightening.

-The different dinosaurs available now is a great selection, which I am sure will increase as time continues.

-Developers seem interested on feedback and are genuinely happy to work on criticism.
-Potential. Potential. Potential.

Off of my head suggestions:
-Player chat should be restricted amongst same genera of dinosaurs.

-Initiating small in game groups with a simple management system that will include chat? While limiting group sizes based on genera (No need for 20 friends to get on and all play as one raptor pack)

-Maybe small edges and perks among certain species to help with hunting and defending. (Example: Rex receives a small notification for dead or wounded prey, and what direction the smell comes from or better hearing for larger herbivores).

-Tail attacks for larger herbivores, swinging in a large motion to defend backside.

-As of now a small or simple stat tracker that gives you feedback per life or genera you play as. (Kills, times escaped attack, deaths, longest single life)
-Blood, wounds on dinosaurs after being attacked or feeding.

-Wounds or being hurt slow you down slightly, and give an indication to carnivores of your general location (sort of like the Rex perk I brought up)

Great, great potential, I do not regret buying the game for the 19.99 price tag but I feel that a lower one would get a larger player base to work with, depending on how the developers see this game going.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I wish there was a neutral review...i really do =P I had a really hard choice as to what to put this review as.

Pros:

- Beautiful Maps

- Beautiful, accurate dinosaurs and animations

- A true 'survival' feel with the need to eat, drink, rest, and a variety of different vocal calls per species

- A variety of Dinosaurs to play, including Herbivores

- If you can get on a Realism server with enforced rules and active mods, it is a lot of fun

Cons:

- Limited Content (understandable in an Alpha game, of course. But if just walking around and trying not to die is not for you, I'd advise waiting for more content.)

- Iffy parts of the community ( but isn't that true of every game?)

- Some Developers are rude and no professional. Encouraging public shaming and trolling, etc (While this does not necessarily affect game play, it's still a huge disappointment to me to see this sort of behavior. I mention this ONLY because some people like to know where their money is going. This did not affect my own decision to purchase the game of course)

- Finding your friends can take an hour or more, especially as you die and have to start over

to sum up:

If you want more in-depth game play, you're better off waiting.

If you are easily offended and don't want your money to support Developers who insult their players and can be rather rude, then you probably want to avoid this game.

I will update this to a positive review when i feel the game deserves it ^^

Resolved issues:

FIXED, you now spawn at half food and half water.
- You spawn starving and dehydrated, and will usually die before reaching a lake to drink (And if you do reach a lake, odds are you will die to a carnivore camping the lake)

-FIXED, resting now hides name tags for all species
Certain species cannot hide their name tags, handicapping them from trying to hide successfully

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Now I have only played 3 hours yes, but since there isn't THAT much content I feel this will do.

I've seen a few comments saying that to enjoy this game you must have a little imagination to really dive into it. This I can say is true. I like feeling that I AM a dinosaur trying to survive in the harsh kill or be killed world. It is definitly more fun if you have friends who will play along side you.

I spoke to some people and they will be adding more content such as NPCs and soon after that an AI system. Which I was happy to hear because there's no way to actually eat (if you are a carnivor) if there's no food. Especially if you are in a server with no players.

The one thing I hope they can add in next to the NPCs is a single player mode. I love when games create modes where you can be online and offline. I feel that this game can have both those options. They definitly need some sort of maping system or maybe like a smell map where you sniff the air and it will tell you where food, water or other dinosaurs are. It is difficult to find my friends when playing after I died or logged in.

I also hope they make it so Herbivours don't die so easily and have a bit more of a fighting chance just as Carnivors do. That way not everyone is choosing Carnivor because Herbivors are hard to play.

Other than those difficulties, I see SO much potential in this game. It is beautifully created for being in early access. Just by seeing the quality now makes me believe there will be so much added to this game down the road. I hope when people buy this they do not quickly discard it. If you really love those type of simulations of survivle and living anothers life than this is a very amazing game.

I can not began to describe how amazing it feels to run with a pack of T-Rexs or trample slowly across the valley with other Long Necks (I love Little Foot so I like to call them Long Necks, same with Sharp Tooths. Shush)

I hope this review was helpful and I hope you enjoy the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has a long way to go, but that's natural for a game that's released Early Access this early on in development. While that does have some disadvantages, I believe the advantages outweigh it as we the players can affect the development of the game with our feedback.

Right now the game is a buggy mess, but that's alright - the development team has been patching it almost every day in the few days it's been out. And unlike a lot of other developers in Early Access, The Isle Development Team has a schedule of what they want to accomplish and when, plus as the game description says - we also affect the development.

The developers are ambitious and it's up to the players to make this game something great. And how many other MMO's out there let you simulate being a dinosaur pack? It's amazing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For a game that is in early access, this is quite something.
The community of which I have encountered based around team work, are very helpful, and have always got your back. My first day, I was struggling to get anything done. Searching for water, and food. Then I found a few other raptors ( I was raptor team ) and they straight away helped me get food and water. And then added me to their group and we all got along and hunted, explored and they showed me 2 of the main places for my species.

The game itself, although as I've said is in early access, it looks beautiful, runs smoothly besides the odd bug every now and then but I haven't personally came into any, it's animations are pretty fluid, and there is definately pleanty more updates to come I'm sure.

I've always wanted a dinosaur RPG survival game, and THIS is THE game I've always wanted!!!

The game as it currently is will not be the game it will be later on in development as the devs are using it as a testing ground for various different things. It's more or less a playground at the moment. However it is still very enjoyable and there is still a survival feel to it as it is now.

You will die.
It happens. It could be a predator that gets you, it could be another of your species or faction". This game isn't for those who take things personally and/or those who get upset when another person kills them

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bought this convinced that it would never leave Early Access, never achieve optimal or even mediocre performance, never polish a single feature and knowing it has a standard cancerous community. If you're prepared to throw away all of your delusions and waste a little money, you too will go on meaningless multi-hour walks that ends with a server crash, or stomp on rubberbanding dinosaurs as a Puertosaurus at spawn lake, or just absorb the immersion of a general chat during naptime with your herd.

If you don't like wasting huge amounts of time interacting with people in a barebones cashgrab, then I can't recommend that you play The Isle.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Now we have hit a considerable milestone for the game with it's recent patch! I think it's worth a updated review of some of the new content.

The game continues to be the Dino survival/sim it has always been up to this point! Other reviews will tell you what the games about if your new. Go read one of them then come back here to see what's new! :) Anyway thanks to some new mechanics and features this game is becoming really really really good!.

Combat is now brutal, but fair thanks to the new addition of a bleed mechanic which causes you to lose health over time if you suffer damage. If you try and run away while bleeding you will suffer a huge constant health drain, you have to literally stop and rest if you wan't to minimise blood loss (As in real life). This creates panic moments when your bleeding out as to what to do next! Plus this makes small Dino's no pushover! (Thank god!) I used to laugh as a Carno when I saw a Raptor... Now im very on edge as I know it could easily take me down if I make a wrong move. The bleed mechanic is a great thing and adds realism to the game!
This is paired greatly with visual damage on your dino when you are injured! Huge cuts, claw marks, scars and the fact you do visually bleed if you have been bitten! All this will be shown! Again another nice thing to add to the realism and the immersion.. Also shows other Dino's that you are potential food!

Long grass although been out for a while now aids small Dino's like the Austroraptor greatly for hunting and hiding. Same goes for Galli and Dryo players, bigger Dino's such as Rex while far stronger need to keep a close eye out when travelling through these areas! I have seen packs of Raptors bring down the biggest of predators through using long grass to ambush!
Footprints have also been added! You can now literally follow a Dino's recent footstep trail! Great for when your on the hunt! Beware that goes for you too though :P

These are just some of the things that have been recently added. The game is showing more and more promise as it continues through it's development, but do note it still has bugs, crashes from time to time, mechanics which need a bit more polish, balance issues and sometimes the game might not work altogether for whatever reason! If you can deal with that pick it up now and support the game. If you can't, but your interested keep a close eye on it! It's worth it's weight and then some!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

im going to get beef for this.

my pc is a tad bugged so apologies for lack of caps or appropriate puncuation. basically, as an early access game the game does change drastically, and this is my reason for changing this review, which was positive with the exception of a bad rage review rant i had

basically, the community is an absolute killjoy in this game, and that says alot considering alot of people have problems with the dev team being rude and i dont

this is a problem that has gotten worse and worse as the game develops and the community develops. the games mechanics, models, and features are extremely well done. but this means nothing when the gameplay/community completely shuts down their uses

where to start. lets do a hypothetical scenario where ur playing as a carno, my favorite dinosaur. now, you just want to go down to the local lake to catch a bite of a random corpse and to get a drink. moment you get there you're either chased out or killed by a good majority of dinosaurs already there. that, my freind, is 'dinosaur racism' most players tend to judge an entire species based off of one bad crowd and as a result most dinosaurs are shut down because of it.

ok, now lets say you got away but you werent able to catch a bite, but you see a diabloceratops, a perfect meal if you know what you're doing. you get in and get out, managing to get it to bleed. it starts to limp, it's life force starts to fade, you can taste the delicious flesh already. then all of a suddenly a tyrannosaurus sneaks up on you, crushes your ribcage and kills you. in the killcam you can see it making sure the diabloceratops is ok, watching over it as it rests. that my freind is a carebear. i actually founded that term, along with dinoman i beleive, and since then has expanded to beyond this game. these guys can completely starve predators as not only do they guard live herbivores but they also tend to guard corpses.

finally, you're fed up. being a predator is too stressfull. so you decide to be a herbivore, a big defensive one - triceratops. this guy is big and defensive. he looks like a guy that you wouldnt want to mess with. perfect for you cause you just want to hang out with other herbivores and eat plants. you spawn in and manage to make it to a grove of trees and start chowing down. a tyrannosaurus approaches you, freindly calling, trying to carebear you. you don't exactly care about that kind of thing so you do a threaten call to tell him no. you can tell he gets disgruntled and leaves. 6 minutes later you here footsteps behind you. you look to find that the said rex has come back with a whole other pack of rexes. they chase you down and eat you. respawning it becomes apparently that being a tough defensive herbivore usually means that if you keep to yourself you're garunteed to get slaughtered by megapacks.

see what im getting at here?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

60+ hours played.  I got the game after watching some YouTube videos.  It looked very fun in those so I gave it a shot.  And it WAS fun for the first week or so, until they introduced a leg-breaking mechanic which makes you sit around for 2 minutes to 2.5 hours (depending how big your dino is) for your broken leg to heal, during which time you can only crawl and most other dinos will view you as dead, which you basically are.  I've waited to see if it was intended to be this bad and now I've seen dev confirmation that it is.

I should have read the game description closer before buying and it's my fault for not doing so:

Over time
date: the game will be updated to the point of intended hardcore functionality. As this happens
recommended:
difficulty will gradually become more brutal and chances of survival become less likely."

I personally want more fun and less brutal in my games so I think this is where I get off.

Regarding polish
hoursPlayed: the game feels like an alpha currently.  You can play and probably not crash often
voteText: but disconnects are a little frequent and almost no part of the UI is good (there's a bar for Stamina
helpfulPercent: Food
votesHelpful: & Water
votesTotal: but not for your health--and you do die when you get to 0).  You spawn in a random location and basically need to get to one of the lakes because that's where the other people are
votesFunny: a journey that can take 1-20 minutes if nothing bad happens to you on the way (see: leg breaking).  Short of memorizing the map
commentsCount: the only way to get to known places is to keep your debug screen up
column16: which puts distracting writing all over the screen
column17: while you watch 2 extra long coordinates at the top and try to keep going in the proper direction.  The lakes are largely bursts of massacres but that's pretty much all you can do at the moment.  Some people try to roleplay but it's ultimately silly when others will just attack you anyway.  I was a triceratops and resting next to another one in a herd of herbivores.  Then he got up and just killed me out of the blue before I could react.  Sweet
column18:
see you guys in 20 :)

I'll maybe re-assess at a later point but I wouldn't recommend it to my friends at the moment so I can't recommend it to anyone else.

And yes
column19: the lead dev (at least) is quite brash.  It's not my cup of tea but I know some people think it's great so YMMV."

Don't get me wrong, THIS IS A GREAT GAME just make sure you can run it very well.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As an early access game it's difficult to judge this. I'll try and keep it simple:

Pro's

It looks fantastic. The skins and general environment, including the soundscape, are entirely right for a game of this kind.

It runs really well (for me at least) I've played it for several hours and the only thing I found was the occasional drop out of the Xbox controller. I can't be sure this was the game and assume it wasn't.

The play area is huge and with a bit of experience you could really use the environment to your advantage, either for hiding or hunting. It's not just for show, it actually works.

There's plenty of choice in terms of what you play.

The character animations and actions are realistic.

The chat system works well without getting in the way.

It's highly configurable.


Cons

Whilst the core game works, it isn't explained at all. Some of it is obvious, other parts less so. Figuring it out and setting things up while you're getting eaten alive can be tricky. If you want a soft landing do a bit of reading beforehand.

There's no map. Whilst this may add to the realism it does make gameplay frustrating at times. There is a system you can use tied to the dev options but it's not too user friendly.

When you die (which you will) you're returned to a spawn point. I'm not 100% sure if this is the same one or if there's a few. Either way it can be some distance from where you were. You can see the sense in this as otherwise the dino attacking you could just rinse/repeat for XP but it's a bit frustrating. The trick is don't die.

Overall despite the gripes it's a good game. Having watched the Devs stream on Twitch you can see it's got huge potential so it's worth it just for that.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've played this game for quiet a while now and I feel I can put out a decent review.

First off, I have enjoyed dinosaurs since I was a kid, watched all the documentaries about them whenever they came out. VHS's of Walking With Dinosaurs ;)

Anyway, I first started playing it I was scared ****less, I was a Carnotaurus, whomping around the forest, not knowing what I was doing. I was aware there are bigger things then me!

Further I went into the forest learning my way around, trying to find things to feed my hunger. After 10 minutes of crouch walking, I heard a large thud. I stopped and looked around, low and behold it was a Tyrannosaurus Rex. I feared for my life, I hid behind a ridge of rocks and waited for it to pass. I am to the point of no water and food, I am panicking.

Finally at some point I see something in the distance, water, a large body of water! I went over their super cautious and began to drink. I noticed Herbivores eating and lumbering about, as the days go by of me playing this game I got to try out every single species and see pretty much every map and check out every inch of it.

This game is simply amazing, different and those negative comments are stupid. Oh you spent like less then an hour playing not seeing everything for what it is?

Yes this game does have a few bugs Not many to cry about and quit"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you are interested in purchasing this game, I suggest you hear me out.
The Isle has absolutely outstanding potential. There are many dinosaurs to choose from with a great variety of skins, ranging from herbivores to carnivores; humans are claimed to be coming soon. All of these dinosaurs have unique traits (attacks, health points, call/roar and skin variation, etc.) and unique people who play as them. You can choose any dinosaur you want with no restrictions (at the moment), whether it be a helpless and small dryosaur to a fast and powerful shantungosaurus. You can form herds of your own species, plan secretly with species chat, or plot points in which you are interested to travel to. The community is great- with the average expectation of a few obnoxious players, even though the developers may not be the kindest of people.
If you’re looking for nice, helpful, and generous developers who strive to complete their goals for the benefits of their customers, stay clear from their live streams. The developers are nasty, cold-hearted, and ultimately insult and annoy their customers (not a very smart business decision). Only some (probably only one) developers are actually mature and normal people. Aside from all the potent drama- that could be the downfall of this game- here are some pros and cons of the game (do consider that this is an early access review):
PROS:
-Great variety of dinosaurs that are updated weekly.
-Great gameplay when regarding an early access game.
-Regular bug fixes.
-Weekly updates.
-Great simulation potential.
-The ability to form herds and/or packs with other dinosaurs.
-Species chat, which enables players to plot secretly when hunting, foraging, or travelling.
-Various calls to signal others without use of chat.
-Engaging wilderness.
-Very positive community.
-Suggested issues are usually addressed and resolved as soon as possible.
-Large maps with great potential.
-Lists of stats such as health and stamina.
-Intense (though mostly calming) survival simulation.
-Well-paced development.
-Outstanding and smooth animation.
-Great graphics for an early access game.

CONS:
-Developers who trash (insult) the community with horrible attitude.
-Live streams filled with countless swears and slurs.
-Large maps with no available tracking-maps (at the moment).
-No ability to choose spawn-point areas (at the moment).
-Lack of foliage (at the moment).
-Unbalanced dinosaurs such as the Tyrannosaurus Rex (who has WAY too much health).
-Powerful dinosaurs that were downgraded for no reason (shantungosaurus).
-Uncomfortable and anticlimactic combat.
-Occasional lag and poor game performance.
-Large maps that prove to be a nettlesome task when traversing upon.
-Trotting doesn’t really look like… Trotting…
-Various glitches that can break the game or interrupt gameplay (as to be expected).
-Not many underdog dinosaurs (tupandactylus, prionsuchus, suchomimus, pachycephalosaurus etc.).
-This game does not have archaeopteryx. D:
-Requires a beefy computer (not an issue for me, but may be for some without beefy PC’s).

NOTE: Do not get this game with the intention that it well be never-ending fun, as it can get boring when there is a lack in content.

EXTRA: COMMUNITY SUGGESTIONS
I don't know if this will be any use to you [developers], but I traveled to random servers and asked random people about the dinosaurs they would most like to see. I'm thinking of conducting a poll later on, but for now, here are the results:
Tupandactylus (POPULAR), Pachycephalosaurus (REALLY POPULAR), Corythosaurus, Igunadon, Yutyrannus (POPULAR), Allosaurus, Ceratosaurus, Prionsuchus, Suchomimus (POPULAR), Ankylosaurus, Shunosaurus, Utahraptor, Rajasaurus, Pteranodon, Spinosaurus, Sarcosuchus, Giganotosaurus, Kaprosuchus, Archeopteryx (NOW POPULAR). That is all for now, I may conduct a poll later on.

GAME RATING: 7/10 (This may change later on). [C+]
Needs work but has exceptional potential.
-Iyan A

reviewText:
Early Access Review

UPDATE EDIT: Glad to see everything in the past was worked out. However the game has been taking some pretty annoying downfalls. The idea of all the issues is understandable, raptors being fast, ect. Yet somehow with the larger map, and decreased stamina it has made the game literally unplayable. It takes hours to find another player on the map, and finding food and water is near impossible since it takes forever to get anywhere. The least you could do is give us a spawn point nearby one of the active lakes. Starting out starving and thirsty makes this an even larger feat, because by the time you reach water or food, you're already pretty much dead and someone kills you with one hit.

I'm overall impressed with the amount of updating and fast fixes, but the game just isn't there yet. Flowing rivers, and intelligent npcs might make the task of playing less tedius, while keeping the game just as difficult as the developers want it to be. We understand you want the map to be large, and the game to be challenging, but there's a point where it goes from challenging to just plain boring from waiting forever. Personally I think stationary spawn points for each species near a general spot would be an excellent fix without having to change anything. The dinosaurs are down perfect, but everything else isn't.

So as it stands for now, my review remains negative.

UPDATE EDIT: Art theft? Really guys? Talk about a poor dev leader, hopefully you feel ashamed of that, not to mention that now we have no skins to change into. I'm kind of mad at myself for buying the game now that I cant get a refund, I don't want to support an abusive dev. If you continue this way, the game isn't going to get finished. Suggest the others wait until there's a finished product befoe you buy this, because I'm certain things will go downhill from here.

UPDATE EDIT: Nice! I was finally able to play it, took awhile for me to update my review so my apologies about that. I like the dinosaurs and their skins, very beautiful! However the enviroment could use a lot of work for a new age game. I myself and perfectly content with the way it is now, but I know people who are to hard on graphics so if that's something you really care about then this game probably isn't for you.

You aren't able to play as humans or cannibals yet, but I don't really care to be honest. I'm curious as to how that updates in the future, and how they play seperately. Something that annoys me is the chat option, there should be both a species chat, and a public chat. Not being able to communicate with all players can be difficult and causes a lot of confusion, especially if you are the only one playing as that species.

I really enjoy the way the game plays so far, and was extremely excited to hear that isn't even all the dinosaurs they will be adding. Personally I would like to see an accurate representation of Dilophosaurus for once (sick of seeing the ridiculous Jurassic park version, it's pathetic), so I hope that will be a thing if they do add it. Otherwise other dinosaurs which would be interesting to see if they add them are Leaellynasaura, Ankylosaurus, Triceratops, Giganotosaurus, Microraptor, and Spinosaurus.

One thing that annoyed me though, and still does, is the unfair balancing of some dinosaurs. The raptor class is way too fast, and can kill any slower moving dinosaur without a scratch just by being behind their attacks, even the T-rex and other towering beasts. There literally was no possible way for me to get to them, and some would kill people for no reason at all and wouldn't give it up. The power of some of the dinosaurs seems strangely nerfed compared to others, and are pointless to be whatsoever. Understanding this is early access though, I can safely believe this will be fixed in the future.

Overall it's a wonderful game, and worth my purchase so far.


FIRST REVIEW: I understand this is pre-alpha, but I have the requirements and cannot open the game. It first loaded up, showed the screen, so I wanted to change the settings. As soon as I did that it keeps crashing, even after I restart it, it crashes. Hopefully this will be noticed and patched. I would love to try the game. Depending on th situation, I'd wait until later to jump in :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Oh boy, where to start. So many dino fans were hyped for a little game called The Stomping Land many moons ago. Needless to say, it didn't last, with an unfinished mess of a game being left, along with the beautiful models they made for the dinos. Skip to 2015 and a demo for a game called The Isle was released. In the month of December this game was released into early access.

So far the game plays perfectly fine, with the player picking from a dinosaur of either the herbivore or carnivore side, with flyers and aquatics sooner or later showing up. Do I recommend this game for Dino fans? Hell yes. But keep in mind, it is early access, so many things are subject to change, such as the ability to be any dino/reptile you want from the start. That being said, if you do happen to be community friendly then beware of The Isle, as it's mostly full of people crying over the Devs releasing a certain animal *Looking at you Quetz 'fans'* or just whinning in general. So other than that, there isn't much to be bothered about, other than the odd bug or two in say the terrain. So, what are you waiting for reading this random review? Go buy it and throw your money to the Devs and buy this game, and throw some tips to Levia for more smexy skins.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So far, I love this game. There are so many pros to it, I'll just list a few of the cons I see with it.
Maps. They are HUGE and the coords are very confusing.
The ability to choose a spawn point, or CREATE one---such as with a nest or a den of some sort acting a respawn after you die. That way it doesn't take packs/herds 30 minutes to regroup after being killed. ITs extremely frustrating, especially for new players that don't know the maps.

T-rex's are super OP right now, meanwhile, the Peurtas---who are so huge they should do massive damage---don't do anything. As a raptor, I could sit there and whittle away at their health, eventually killing one and it could smack me around and did almost nothing to me.

PACK DYMANICS: There are none. You friendly fire and kill herd/pack mates all too easily. It would be wonderful if you could bring someone into your herd/pack and they become non-attackable, and viceversa.

Bring back the raptor's pouncing!

The ability to back up rather than turn around, that way we don't fall off a cliff when we get too close by accident.

Eating is a pain in the butt, super finicky. I have to either be directly on top of a plant, inside of the meat-bag I want to nom or nibbling at its nose in order to grab it.

The galli's sounds need to be fixed. Bigger rex roars! BIGGER!

Add a flying dino into the game---I'd kill to be a pteranadon, even if you never added another dino ever again.

To sum it up, the biggest problem is that map---too much map, too hard to find players or even npc dinos. Its pretty ridiculous.
Otherwise, i cannot wait to see what you guys do with the game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ignoring the apparent issues with the devs and community, I can say that their small team works very hard to provide a fun experiance to those who wish to play a harsh social survival/dinosaur simulator game.

This is just my personal opinion of the game!

Pros:

- Constant updates with new and exciting features
- Growing pool of dinosaurs to pick from, both Carnivore and Herbivore
- Large detailed maps to roam
- Large server support
- Tough gameplay where you have to use wits to survive
- Highly detailed dinosaurs with great animations
- Fantastic sound effects
- Amazing sunsets (I love taking screenshots)

Cons:
- 'Friendly' community at best, the servers currently lack moderation. (Not the dev's or games fault however!)
- Some improvements to performance are needed.
- Config/options menu not fully completed (Not a big issue to be honest)
- Lacks easy tools for private server moderation (Again not a massive issue but can sometimes mean servers need to restart to ban players)

All in all, I personally love this game as it has provided hours of fun gameplay and put me in the shoes of a dinosaur trying to survive in a ever-changing enviornment. Providing many different challenges to the player depending on the species they choose.

reviewText:

If you want to help with development by financial contribution - YES

If you are buying a game - NO

If you are reading this short review during sale and this product is priced at 6,99€ or less than go ahead and buy it even though it has many flaws listed below because it is well worth 7 bucks.

cons:

1. Dondi´s vision of hardcore survival game as it is implemented now in the isle (april 2016) is rewarding for those who sit by the lake and take selfies instead of doing stuff with other people in world (taking selfies with other people does not count). Why?:

- HEALING TAKES AGES. For some dinos it means 50HP per tick which is every 2 minutes. Most dinos hit you for more than 100HP. If your dino has more than 1000HP and you loose more than 50% of health, it is more effective to just suicide because you can run to same place with full health faster than if you healed as it was intended.

- it takes at least 15 minutes to heal broken leg, in order to heal broken limb you have to sit still and do nothing because if you don´t, it will take 30 minutes to heal. Once again, suicide is faster. Even if you get worst spawn ever, you will be there faster)

You can stare at picture of a dinosaur of your choice for 30 minutes for free, higher fps and multiplatform compatibility guaranteed.

2. Negative feedback is always met with hostility or ignored. It doesn´t matter if you write your opinion about something in very polite manner, use sound arguments or even math to support your view on things. It doesn´t matter if you are new player or well respected and universaly liked member of the comunity - the dev response is always salty and you will most likely be labeled as whiner and ridiculed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Shows a lot of potential but, at this point in time the game is completely unplayable. Here's how a typical session works. Boot the game, join a server and select your killing machine of choice. Proceed to run around completely lost unless you use the debug console for about 20-30 minutes(not exaggerating at all here unfortunately) before encountering another player, the server then crashes and forces you to reload the game as in most cases after a server crash your client will not load into another game until it has been restarted. Why? you ask? Well when joining a game after a server crash your client will immediately crash upon loading into the new server. After reloading the game and rejoining the server you get to hope that the server saved where you were or else you'll be loaded back to a spawn point. Upon finally finding another player its a 50-50 chance that they will kill you on sight thus starting the cycle over again. There are a few MAJOR flaws that make this alpha unplayable and it's not the technical issues listed.

Why is it unplayable?

1. Broken legs. The smallest drop will cause you to break your leg which reduces your already snails pace movement speed to even slower molasses-like speed. I have heard that they can heal in time but i've not been able to reproduce the effect even after waiting for 10-15 minutes in rest mode. At which point you could have simply respawned and walked back to the place you were when you had your unfortunate incident. Which brings me to my next point.

2. Respawning. It's not actually the respawning mechanic that is the issue here, it's getting to that mechanic that presents the problem. A sensible person would implement a feature that allows you to respawn in a timely fashion as to avoid issues like getting stuck, falling through the world, wanting to respawn and see other locations etc etc. I'm happy to report that this is indeed possible however there is one major problem with this mechanic. You can only do it 15 minutes after spawning or logging into a server, which ever was most recent. You can kiss your social life and even dinner goodbye if you want to respawn. The developers excuse for having this feature on such a lengthy timer is that the extra bodies produced by respawning cause server instability. This however is complete BS as any even half competent fool knows that the developer could simply add code to delete the illegitimate frustration baby produced by offing yourself when respawning. This leads to long, slow, frustraiting and unfun skifs of gameplay where you're simply limping around with your broken ♥♥♥ legs trying to find the nearest cliff to end your suffering. I could go on and on about how terrible this is and why it's really bad in an alpha to restrict the feature but I digress.

3. Stamina. So all of the playable dinosaurs in the game have a stamina pool, this governs actions like sprinting and jumping and some attacks. This pool is 1k points for most characters, some higher. This pool regenerates naturally at about 1 point every 2-3 seconds which on it's own sounds horrible but it's really not that bad as you can simply rest to regenerate stamina. I assume this is designed this way so when you're fighting other players you cant simply run away from losing fights by running in a straight line to oblivion leaving your aggressor helpless to do anything except watch his delicious dinner slowly run away. The issue is that this pool of stamina regenerates at about 10  points per second when resting. This means if you want to cover any meaningful amount of distance you're going to have to run for about 1 minute, rest for 3 and run for a minute and so on and so forth. This leads to long long waits to get to any given point on the map, we're talking 10-20 minute run backs" after death in most cases. Anyone who played early WoW understands the pains of long run backs
date: now imagine that world without flight points and mounts you can only use for 1 minute. Yeah.... its bad....\n\nIn summary these three major pain points lead to a slow
hoursPlayed: and unfulfilling experience. I understand that this game is still in alpha and has some major distance to cover but
voteText: that is no excuse for these issues as they are DESIGN choices. These problems could be remedied in a matter of hours if not minutes if the developer so chose to do so. I don't expect that these issues will be fixed or even looked at as issues thus leading to the early death of this title as the developer seems to be focused on introducing new content(theres already plenty to have a solid experience) rather that ensuring that the game is actually fun to play.\n\nIt could be argued that it is still very early in development and that the dev is simply following a bucket list of items to complete as to ensure a timely release but with the direction that development is headed and the lack of attention to bug fixes
helpfulPercent: it starting to paint a grim future for this title which is sad because there is a ton of potential in this idea but like planetside 2
votesHelpful: the bugs
votesTotal: quality of life issues
votesFunny:
and lack of insight into the reasons that games sometimes fail will cause this title to slowly fade away into abandonment or simply sputtering out. It's not too late at this point so I'll be checking in periodically to make sure this review stays fair.


All that being said
commentsCount: I (sadly)CANNOT recommend this alpha title for purchase even for those who simply "want to check it out"."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Be warned, the game is still bare bones currently, and features are still being added. So if you want a finished game now, do not buy this yet.

The game is headed in a great direction, and the developers are amazing, they even stream themselves playing, answering questions about, and developing the game. They update frequently as well. The game is very well optimized, and looks beautiful (though they have major changes planned in the future too). They want to make the game scary, gory,and horrific.

Right now (as of this review), there is only about 10 Dinosaurs, but they plan to add dozens more, as well as multiple classes of humans. I'm truly excited!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Essentially you get to choose from different classes of dinosaurs, each with their own perks, and all extrememly well modeled and animated. This game feels REAL. The point is to survive, however, there will soon be a progression system in place which they are already beginning to implement, so essentially you will start out small and choose from lower end dinos/humans and fight to survive, earn points, and work your way up the food chain. This isnt a building/hoarding sim, its raw survival. If you are looking for a building sim with dinos go buy ark, if you want realistic prehistoric survival simulation you have come to the right game. I have already put over 100 hours into this game in its infant stages, money well spent as is.

Another good thing is that the developers are constantly putting out meaningful, and well done updates to improve gameplay. The game came out early december, and it has already become unrecognizable from the game i first purchased, so this so far is definitely not a repeat of TSL at all, and is way farther in development than TSL ever was. We've gotten multiple new dinosaurs, new maps (including a nice HD one I like alot), new roars/vocal noises to communicate with others, resting, ect... overall a great game and strangely addicting

The game is great and I absolutely loved it, but the devs really don't give a ♥♥♥♥ about fixing glaring problems, and are especially rude to low-class players.

I can now no longer play the game at all due to the decisions of the devs. The grass is extremely dense and there is no way to disable it or make it less dense from the graphics menu, so previously, you had to use the console. Instead of fixing the badly optimized grass, they removed the ability to change it entirely, making literally HUNDREDS of players unable to play the game. Servers that once held 50-100 players all the time are now empty.

Good job, idiots. If you don't have the reccomended specs, DO NOT BUY THIS GAME. reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIn the games current state i can't recommend it to anyone other than super hardcore dinosaur enthusiasts who just want to see the models. Problems with the community aside there just isn't enough game here to warrant even a discounted price. You spawn in, and see what your dinosaur is like (at the time of writing this one of them doesn't even have any sound) and proceed through a prehistoric landscape to find some other dinosaurs to interact with. Except there aren't. The game has no npcs, most servers have a limit of 75 people or less, and the map is ridiculously huge. Topping that off with an inability to choose a spawnpoint can mean that you end up wandering an empty wasteland for almost 2 hours without finding anyone to interact with, any food to eat, or water to drink. In its current state it's a dinosaur walking simulator and nothing more.
