reviewText:
Early Access Review

In its current state, this is more of a dinosaur simulator.
How many games can say that, though? Nearly every (playable) dinosaur game pits you against people with guns. Ironically, this one is no different- but the focus is entirely on survival.

There are currently 13 dinosaurs (NO humans yet), and the models are very high quality. You spawn into the island half-hungry & thirsty. The maps are very WIP, but can still be nice to look at.

Combat, unfortunately, is very underwhelming at the moment. The lack of an S/backpedal key makes it very easy to expose your backside to attackers. Despite the lack of a scent trail system (yet), hunting & stalking prey can be very exciting.

Official servers are bit a dodgy, but the community makes up for this with group-based 'realism' servers of their own.

The final release will have civilized & uncivilized humans as well as mutated genetic experiments- both human and dinosaur. Like ARK:SE, you will be able to tame dinosaurs. Unlike ARK, this does not mean assimilation through narcotics. Player dinos will be tameable and can kill their trainer at any time.

There are plans to lock bigger dinosaurs behind a progression system, with enough stat upgrades to make you reconsider going straight for the bigger dinosaurs. The game is also going to slowly become hardcore survival- making you drop down a dino-tier when you die OR reseting your progress (depending on if you have a respawn-nest built). There will be different gamemodes (e.g. dino only, free roam, etc.).



To whom it may concern:

Despite everything about this game being AAA, the developers don't take very many strides in being professional. They DO have concise information on development and update this 'round the clock; this feels more like a group of friends coming together to make something (beautiful) happen, rather than a studio getting paid to focus exclusively on the project.
They're a bit brazen when it comes to dealing with unwarranted flak and the project leader won't hesitate to be facetious.
The developers have adopted a line of thinking that prevents the community from being abusive and walking all over them- that's it. They don't act mean for the sake of being mean- 9 times out of 10 they're dealing with a very vocal minority.
I want to see this game through till its release, the devs have a plan in mind and are sticking to it.

Product received for free

Early Access Review

First of all, the reviews are filled with people angry at the devs because they are rude and bad. Man the ♥♥♥♥ up people. Dont expect these people to kiss your ♥♥♥. You should review the game in general, your non-constructive, endless paragraphs of you crying about it don't help no one.

Then, about the game itself.

I really freaking love it. I haven't played as much as other people, but I've played enough to see all the progress they've made through the months, may it be about the look of the game or the gameplay. We can choose between many dinosaurs, herbs or carnivors, and many more are coming to fill up the list. Then you can enter beautiful, hand-made maps filled with various other dinosaurs. The immersion is incredible and as a dinosaur fan, this is the game I have been waiting for. It's beautiful and we aint even at half of what they've planned.

If you're like me and enjoy playing a dinosaur with friends hunting, exploring and the likes, jump on it.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nDespite still being in development, this game is awesome! It is extremely rare to find a game where you can actually play as the dinosaur, rather than a human taming or killing the dinosaurs. As it's designed to be open world there is a whole heap of space to explore. Having said that, they are still figuring out the game mechanics, so no mini map to help you find water, you have to rely on the overlay screen coordinates. I am also hoping that there will be non player dino spawns added as well, because at the moment, if playing as a carnivore you need to be able to seek out other players to satiate your hunger and there are only limited numbers of players in each server at one time - if you are the only one in the server you are likely to start starving.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pros
-Graphics are awesome.
-Ton of potential.

Draws
-Map size

Cons
-Character physics

There's not too much to do right now but there's definitely a lot of potential and it seems like every time I get on something new has been added or tweaked and more players are starting to join. The maps are huge, which can be good but there's no map, so a lot of your time can be spent by yourself potentially wondering in circles.  Character checks and balances needs more tweaking; Rex's just get destroyed by everything, blind spots due to turning radiuses are easily exploited, and it seems like herbivores can end up dominating the games sometimes and are way over powered.  Overall I really like this game!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nWell, see, this game is great. My computer doesn't support the higher quality textures or anything like that but I don't need that. It's great with low quality. There's a different range of people, young to older. The oldest I've met on there was 27, and the youngest, not sure but from records, 13. Though they're not all that bad, focusing on the game or just simply making friends with each other. I've made plenty of friends/allies in the past few days while playing this game. I'm sure that once it's complete it will be a big hit, though I'm not too sure how these others might feel. The Isle is introducing humans to the game some time, right? And there's also a wide-range variety of dinosaurs, right? Well see, some people might see this game as a copy of Ark: Survival Evolved. Though it really isn't because you can play as dinosaurs without a mod and it's much more simpler. Overall, though, I highly suggest The Isle (:

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've had the game The Isle for about 2 to 3 months now, and I can honestly say that it is one of my favorite games. I am personally happy with my purchase. Other people may disagree, as I have heard some people complaining (about stupid things might I add.. they rarely have good arguments.)  but again, I personally really enjoy the game.
The game has a LOT of potential, and I can't wait to see what the game will look like in the future. The Isle has come such a long way from where it has started already, and even when I first bought the game I was extremely happy with how it was turning out.
The devs do a great job of keeping the community informed and updated on what is going on with the game.  I want to thank the Devs for all there hard work on The Isle, I feel like they don't get appropriated enough sometimes. They do spend a lot of there time working and developing the game, so I ask you to please be respectful.

In conclusion, I highly recommend this game. It does need a GOOD computer to play, however. So be careful about that.  -Taylor.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

You're walking around as a rex.. suddenly, the wail of a diablo erupts through the silence that engulfed you before. You begin making your way towards the sound where you last heard it. You see it, it's limping.. You rush towards it, the diablo stares at you reluctantly. You roar at it passively. The tension in the air releases and you feel a light, happy feeling.

Suddenly, you are emotionally attatched to that diablo.. You do everything you can to protect it, bring it to food and water.
You treat that diablo as if it were your own child.

All of a sudden, a stegosaur makes it way towards you and your diablo. It aggressive-roars and attacks you as well as the diablo. Eventually killing you both. It all happened so fast.

You respawn as a raptor.

Ouch.. You are upset. Is the diablo even upset? This is weird, why are you upset? It's just a game.

Suddenly, you are sworn to kill every stego you come across.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Frankly, this game is spectactular. Alot of work has and will be put into this game and it's dinosaurs.
I see alot of potential in The Isle.. I see that it's gonna get even more entertaining with the mercs and cannibals that will be coming, along with the quetzalcoatus, the first flying dinosaur of The Isle.
--
10/10 would dino again.

Early Access Review

The game is early access, so there's not much to do at the moment; but it is such a fun premise - walk around as a dinosaur and try to survive - and the graphics are very beautiful; that you end up hooked on it anyways.
There are still quite a few bugs and this game certainly has a long way to go if it is to live up to it's full potential, but I absolutely recommend it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In it's current state the game is till quite empty and with very few NPCs around. Being in early access it's to be expected though, so you can't judge it based on that at all.
It is, however, a ton of fun if you're a dinosaur fan/enthusiast.
The balance feels right, the sounds are really excellent and properly loud, and it's bringing the kid in me alive again to be walking around as a Gallimimus or a Carnotaurus. Many more dinos and impressive other content is planned for the game.
The updates are regular and it shows great promise. I'm proudly supporting this one.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nDespite still being in development, this game is awesome! It is extremely rare to find a game where you can actually play as the dinosaur, rather than a human taming or killing the dinosaurs. As it's designed to be open world there is a whole heap of space to explore. Having said that, they are still figuring out the game mechanics, so no mini map to help you find water, you have to rely on the overlay screen coordinates. I am also hoping that there will be non player dino spawns added as well, because at the moment, if playing as a carnivore you need to be able to seek out other players to satiate your hunger and there are only limited numbers of players in each server at one time - if you are the only one in the server you are likely to start starving.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love the Isle a lot, it does need a lot of work but it's a freedom game where your survive literally as a prehistoric beast.
It can be slow, but facing the endless hunts, evading packs of carnivores, or spending extended amounts of time tailing a herd from the trees...

Personally, I love the reality of that. There are some funny moments being that every other dinosaur is another player, but a lot of people do take it seriously. Species sectioned themselves with their own kind, protecting themselves and the herd. This includes things that happen in nature such as sacrificing one member so the herd can survive, practicing flanking a herd to cut off one from the group.

It can even be peaceful, just sitting all together in a lake or a field, carnivores and herbivores safe together.

I adore this game so much, it updates so often. 4 new species have arrived in the span of about 2 weeks, including other tools to help make the game easier to play and understand.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Things you should know about this game:
-Yes, it is early access.
-Yes, it does have some bugs and glitches here and there.
-Currently, it's more of an online dinosaur simulator because they haven't added the human and cannibal classes yet.

However.
If you love dinosaurs, online PVP and the fun of hunting and being hunted, you will love this game.
You are able to do various roars and sounds to communicate with other players on whether or not you are friendly or aggressive and chat functions seem to be limited between species (such as, carnivores only type to carnivores and herbivores only type to herbivores). This way, the herbivores won't know if you are talking about eating them as a carnivore. ;)
Each class has it's pros and cons, making every dinosaur a different experience with different challenges. Some people have complained that it's difficult to figure out the controls since the game doesn't have any kind of tutorial, but you honestly can just go into your options and find all the listed controls and keybinds if you are confused.
Being multi-player, obviously it can get a bit frustrating when someone you thought was your packmate ends up taking a bite out of you, but honestly it is half the fun! The game doesn't babysit and it doesn't make things easy for you, making it a challenging life as a dinosaur.
Want to play with friends and have trouble finding eachother? Say no more! Press the insert" key on your keyboard to pull up an information screen which also holds coordinates! If you know how to use them
date: you can find your friends easily. (If you don't have an insert key
recommended: just go into your keybinds and change it to a key you do have)\nWorried about the community or the developers? Concerned they don't care?\nWell
hoursPlayed: like most communities
voteText: there are ups and downs. However
helpfulPercent: the developers are some of the MOST active I've ever seen! They are truly dedicated. Since I downloaded the game they have updated EVERY DAY. I'm not even joking. They regularly listen to complaints and try to fix them ASAP
votesHelpful: and are constantly improving the experience. Just last night they hosted a Livestream where they were answering questions while they showcased their developments on the game!\n\nTLDR; This is a multi-player take on a dinosaur simulator that has dedicated developers and despite being Early Access
votesTotal: is a ton of fun! If you are willing to put up with some glitches and are willing to support an in-progress game
votesFunny: this is definitely for you."

It can be slow, but facing the endless hunts, evading packs of carnivores, or spending extended amounts of time tailing a herd from the trees...

Personally, I love the reality of that. There are some funny moments being that every other dinosaur is another player, but a lot of people do take it seriously. Species sectioned themselves with their own kind, protecting themselves and the herd. This includes things that happen in nature such as sacrificing one member so the herd can survive, practicing flanking a herd to cut off one from the group.

It can even be peaceful, just sitting all together in a lake or a field, carnivores and herbivores safe together.

I adore this game so much, it updates so often. 4 new species have arrived in the span of about 2 weeks, including other tools to help make the game easier to play and understand.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Posting this review to focus on a particular point: Support for operating systems other than PC is slowly coming, though it is definitely behind the primary update level.

PC updates are at 1.9.something whereas Mac updates as still at 1.4.1635 at the time of this review. The main issues with this is that Mac players cannot play on any of the main servers because they all are more updated than we are. Recently there has been a test server available at our update level that we are able to use but the lack of availability has inspired us to get together and form our own group.

We have formed this as a place for Mac users to have their own community in addition to the official Isle discussion forums (due to the fact that our gameplay experience is becoming progressively more different than PC players due to update differences.) We are in the process of setting up our own dedicated server so that Mac players will always have at least one server available to them at all times.

Anyone who is on Mac thinking about playing this game is welcome to join the group, that is where we will be posting updates about the server and will be planning times to play together, etc.


The Isle // Mac Users"  ➔ Connect with the Isle Mac Community

http://steamcommunity.com/groups/TheIsleMacUsers"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Isle. Game Review.

In this review i will adress the good and the bad parts of this game as well as glitches and other various annoyances.

Good Aspects.
-map functions and dinosaur designs are well done and they move without glitches.

-Roars. The roars are very well recorded and sound realistic.

-Stamia, Food and water bars. The desgin for these bars are well done and work well without very many glitches.

-Species only chat. This is a extremely good idea as it adds an element of unpredictablity to the game. If the carnivores cannot see the herbivore chat then they cannot predict how they are going to act how where a herd is.

Bad Aspects and Glitches.
-Tree glitch. The tree glitch is for herbivores that the fact they cannot eat to gain food as the tree doesnt vanish.

-Chat room idiots. For the final version of the game, i demand that certain commands be availble to the public for usage such as /ignore Because some people are to idiotic to even listen to in the chat rooms.

-Dryasaurs. Currently the herbivore Dryasaurs cannot attack anything. Please make this dinosaur atleast have a way to defend itsself cause other than that it is completely useless.

-LAG!. spam roaring causes the game to lag. If there is any way to make the game less laggy that would be appreciated.

Suggestions.
- More tree types for herbivores. IN the final game the bigger and taller Herbivores should be feeding from taller trees while the smaller ones should be feeding on shrubs and ferns close tot he ground. Right now the game only has one type of tree that Herbivores can eat from. And with the glitch it makes it harder for herbivores to find a food sources.

-Omivore class. In the final game there should be the historical accorate three dinosaur classes, the Omivore class should consist of dinosaurs that can both eat meat and plant life. This includes Egg eaters.

-Mini Map. In the final version of the game each server should be able to turn on a Mini map displaying the map and area. This will make it easier for friends to find eachother and for people to find important land marks such as Lakes and Rivers without having to rely on cordinates and wondering. Since not all people can properly ready cordinates.

-Health bar. A bar should be displayed somewhere on the screen to show a dinosaurs health just as the stamia, food and water bars are displayed.

-Nests. Nests should be added as a way of setting a spawn point. Furthermore Egg laying should also be availble to spawn in npcs for a pack.

-Dinosaur genders. Female and Male dinosaurs should have variations in size, colour, and attacks to distinct between the genders.

Final Concusion.

This game is a very well thought out one. But without the mods and developers working together to create and improve it this game will go no where. I do not care about  persoinal issues the develoipers may have. You cannot just stop working on a game once you have started it. NO matter how hard it is to design and implement a game you should alwways keep at it. This game has a very good idea behind it and lets face it there arent may other dinosaur games where you yourself are the dinosaur. However i should warn that I (And hopefully many other people) expect this game to be accurate in the portation of the dinosaurs.  The final release should be fantastic and i know game developers are not miricle workers.

But still i think many people have expectations for the final release of the game. I jsut hope developers can work together to make the game fully made and bug free. Im not expecting a game like Ark Survival Evolved. If this game turned out like that i wouldnt even be able to play it. The game is small enough that my Mac laptop can run it without to much lag on it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have put in a total of 90.2 hours of time into this game so far, I highly recommend it! BUT this is a unique survival game, plus its early alpha! So don't buy it expecting it to stay the same. With each patch they are making this more and more brutal. By brutal I mean if you run at break neck speed and trip over a little ledge then yes you will break your leg. If you lay out in the middle of huge area afk you will most likely die, there is no map for you to find your way, either learn through your surroundings, or through the coordinates they provide. ALWAYS be aware of your surroundings, and DO NOT trust everyone... even people of your own species will attack you at some point.

If you want relaxation and to be left alone, this isn't the game for you. Also the developers don't put up with complaining / whining over how difficult things get or that they haven't released your favorite dinosaure yet. So if you can't handle that then don't buy it... just want to point this out because i've seen negative reviews due to the developers being rude"."

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is a game where you are able to play as a dinosaur, and humans will be added soon, so don't get your gun-holsters or whatever in a twist. This is an ultra-realistic game, and everything is very accurate, including the dinosaurs themselves, and the world. You can even break your leg, which becomes very annoying after a while. Unfortunatley there are a few flaws which kind-of break emmersion/the game itself. Number one and probably the most noticable to new players who have experience with literally any other game which allows you to interact with things (by pressing E), you are unable to eat anything BUT trees. As a smaller dinosaur such as a dryosaurus, or literally anything other than a puertasaurus (The game's currently only sauropod). The next issue is the fact that you may or may not be able to limp or feign limp on water. Another HUGE issue is with sounds. On a lot of dinosaurs, there are one or more calls which do not emit any sound when activated. This may be due to the recent additions of sound settings, but even with the highest sound quality, mainly the 'friendly' (num-bar 2) call and the Generic Roar (f) have been disfunctional for several different creatures. What I think may fix it is either removing the sound quality settings altogether OR making the Epic setting allow and encompass ALL sounds in-game instead of just most of them, which is what I think could be the issue. Another issue involving sounds are the fact that some dinosaurs have the wrong death sounds. For instance, when I am damaged or die as a gallimimus, for some reason I will sound like a carnotaurus. But enough of THAT rant, I am aware this is early access after all. This is overall a good game with  a lot of potential, and I hope this goes on to become a game which could be left to never update again, yet the community would be completely fine with the decision because the game is so polished. A good thing about the game is the growing variety of dinosaurs to play as and the imminent addition of pterosaurs, and eventually aquatic reptiles. Those are just the confirmed ones, what if there will be prehistoric mammals such as Gigantopithicus or Wooly Rhinocerous in the future? Maybe there will be mammal-like reptiles from before the dinosaurs, and maybe even the ancient, HUGE insects such as arthropleaura and meganeura? Titanboa is confirmed, so really the possibilities are endless. Well, maybe they have an end, but there's a heck of a lot of prehistoric creatures. And there's something about making herds in this game that just pumps you up, and the fact that it's so dangerous even for big herds is really cool. Other players definatley are the biggest risk to you, but as long as you have a big enough herd and a fit dinosaur, you'll probably be fine. Humans will add even more to the mayhem. Just imagine, your herd of shantungasaurus is about to fight a pack of t-rex in a clearing. Suddenly a band of hunters walks in on the scene, and suddenly it's a 3-way battle of life and dinner. The scene I have just described will only be even more epic with time and with the end of the game's beta.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is it.
A dinosaur game that finally stands up for what it promises. After the rip-offs with Primal Carnage 2 from beloved fans, after The Stomping Land was left rotting by the one person that brought it to life and after ARK needed more than it could give, comes a dinosaur game that gives everything it can.
And it does so perfectly.

There have been some arguments going around in the dev team, which resulted in the skin designer being fired. A lot of people, including me, were upset and read and listened through lies and truths to find out, what happened. In the end, the game still stands, it still works, and it's still perfect.

As of now, you can choose to be a dinosaur and wander the wilds on different, big maps. You wanna do so as a little Raptor and hide in the high grass? Perfect! You wanna trample the grass as a T-Rex? Go for it! Or you wanna trample the T-Rex as a Broncho? ♥♥♥♥ING YES YOU CAN!
The game offers a lot of varieties of different dinosaurs, maps, attacks, roars and fractions.
You can either roam together as a herd and find others who might join your group, or go alone and hunt others. It's all up to you.
The skins have been taken out as of now (06.02.16) but will be reimplented, maybe even with a Workshop for you own artistic dinosaur skins.

Pro:
- Amazing dinosaur gameplay
- Realistic roars
- Huge maps
- Hunger & Thurst
- Good looking textures
- Easy to get in to
-  Addicting

Con:
- Early Access (Talking out of experience, doesn't necessarily have to be a bad thing.)
That's all I can think of.

As said before, the game is Early Access, which means two things:
- It is being developed as you play it, meaning you pay to test" a product. Depending on your likings
hoursPlayed:
or not so good. The game you're playing right now might not be the final product.
- It might never get finished.

But regardless of those two points

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is a good game, love the idea. You play as a dinosaur in a survival" setting
date: living the day to day life of a dino. They have a decent ammount of dinos in the game right now but it seems everyone only plays Rexes
recommended: seeing how they are the top of the food chain more or less. You spawn into the map at a randomly generated spawn point and work your way towards water and food. As a carnivore you have to hunt other players for food and as herbivores you eat certain trees/bushes depending on what map your playing on. As such being certain dinosaurs have their own perks and cons that make you feel like your part of a dinosaur world.\nOne of the worst things about this game though so far is how people play this "survival" game. Most people consider this game as a dino deathmatch simulator and only spawn in as rexes and go on killing sprees across the map without even trying to survive. Besides that it is great fun to play with your friends or have your friends in the same game as you but as a different specices. To hunt as a pack of raptors is extremely enjoyable. If you want a survival game that you play as a dinosaur instead of the generic human/zombie open world survival game this is def for you."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is my first review for anything on steam. and this game is worthy of me giving the effort. When I bought this game. I could not stop playing. And now it's like 5 days later and I have 35 hours on it.
It's by far one of the best I have played and it's still early access.

What I enjoy about the game:
- massive open world
-impressive looking graphics and landscapes
- the brotherhoods that are born while playing as herbivores. You see one, your instantly friends so that you can survive long enough to fill your belly.
- the overall atmosphere of the game.
- the perilous journeys you have to embark on to find other herds or your food if a carnivore.
- the fact that you don't get a map.....because you are a dinosaur and have no use for one. You have to navigate by landmarks and general direction, adds some butt puckering moments when your walking through a forest and come across a pack of t rexes and your all by your lonesome.
- this is similar to gta online except with dinosaurs. And way better too.

Things I dislike about the game:
- the only real problem I have with it are the servers, but I know these will be tended to as it's still early access.

Overall. This game is amazing. It's truly cut from its own cloth, i recommend buying it. You will not be disappointed, you may be a little lost when you first start as I was, but keep figuring it out and you will have experiences that make you feel as if you are a dinosaur in that ancient hostile world.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is a game where you are able to play as a dinosaur, and humans will be added soon, so don't get your gun-holsters or whatever in a twist. This is an ultra-realistic game, and everything is very accurate, including the dinosaurs themselves, and the world. You can even break your leg, which becomes very annoying after a while. Unfortunatley there are a few flaws which kind-of break emmersion/the game itself. Number one and probably the most noticable to new players who have experience with literally any other game which allows you to interact with things (by pressing E), you are unable to eat anything BUT trees. As a smaller dinosaur such as a dryosaurus, or literally anything other than a puertasaurus (The game's currently only sauropod). The next issue is the fact that you may or may not be able to limp or feign limp on water. Another HUGE issue is with sounds. On a lot of dinosaurs, there are one or more calls which do not emit any sound when activated. This may be due to the recent additions of sound settings, but even with the highest sound quality, mainly the 'friendly' (num-bar 2) call and the Generic Roar (f) have been disfunctional for several different creatures. What I think may fix it is either removing the sound quality settings altogether OR making the Epic setting allow and encompass ALL sounds in-game instead of just most of them, which is what I think could be the issue. Another issue involving sounds are the fact that some dinosaurs have the wrong death sounds. For instance, when I am damaged or die as a gallimimus, for some reason I will sound like a carnotaurus. But enough of THAT rant, I am aware this is early access after all. This is overall a good game with  a lot of potential, and I hope this goes on to become a game which could be left to never update again, yet the community would be completely fine with the decision because the game is so polished. A good thing about the game is the growing variety of dinosaurs to play as and the imminent addition of pterosaurs, and eventually aquatic reptiles. Those are just the confirmed ones, what if there will be prehistoric mammals such as Gigantopithicus or Wooly Rhinocerous in the future? Maybe there will be mammal-like reptiles from before the dinosaurs, and maybe even the ancient, HUGE insects such as arthropleaura and meganeura? Titanboa is confirmed, so really the possibilities are endless. Well, maybe they have an end, but there's a heck of a lot of prehistoric creatures. And there's something about making herds in this game that just pumps you up, and the fact that it's so dangerous even for big herds is really cool. Other players definatley are the biggest risk to you, but as long as you have a big enough herd and a fit dinosaur, you'll probably be fine. Humans will add even more to the mayhem. Just imagine, your herd of shantungasaurus is about to fight a pack of t-rex in a clearing. Suddenly a band of hunters walks in on the scene, and suddenly it's a 3-way battle of life and dinner. The scene I have just described will only be even more epic with time and with the end of the game's beta.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Speaking as someone who bought this game WITHOUT a pre-existing love for dinosaurs - it is still worth it. I was intrigued by the concept of being a dinosaur and their plans for the final product.  I wasn't sure how much fun the game would be in its current state but turns out it's a blast!

As-is, the game can get a bit tedious if you don't find somewhere to go or someone to fight. BUT that is just a result of the early access state and it is definitely fun in short sessions. The dinosaurs and environment are beautiful. The real joy though is experiencing hunting or being hunted, and forming packs or herds with other dinosaurs - especially when you're not the same species as you can only chat with your own kind and have to communicate through the in-game calls" or body language.

Bottom line - this game is worth it for the terror of hiding in a bush as a T-Rex stomps by looking for you and for the thrill of taking down your unsuspecting prey as they dopily frolick about."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After playing the Isle for a few weeks, I have finally decided to give this game a review. It is a game not meant for those that want to live in peace. Not to look at the world and look how wonderful it is.. Because frankly, your leg will break if you keep walking and stare off into space. Or someone will make sure that your first experiance is an exciting one.

No, the Isle is for those that like having things thrown at them at random seconds, and yes one of those might be the server grinding to a wonderous hault. But its still interesting none-the-less. You never know what is going to happen a second or two in the future, or what a server might be like when you have logged on. Even when you pick a server each of them are different in their own way. You can even join a group for those that have realism thrown in, with their own servers.

Many people are turned off by the fact that they believe that the devs are the back end of a donkey, but I could care less. It is a game that take pride in helping work on as a Tester, it keeps an ADD brain like mine happy.. And yes my desk as a few holes in it from the daily Preditora-Sinopa Carnotaurous Wars, but that's what makes the Isle go 'round.

But who am I to tell you what is good and what is bad about this game. Play it for yourself.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a negative Early Access review and, so, not a review of a finished game. This deals with whether or not the game is worth your money at the moment.

At first glance, one might think... oh, good lord, another dinosaur game - doesn't ARK have this covered? Well, not really. Here, for the time being anyway, the focus is on playing as dinosaurs. They say it is a survival game, but like many survival games in early access, it's more of an unbalanced deathmatch. Perhaps, when it's got progression or something to make you actually think more about survival, risk and reward, it may have something to offer. But, at the moment, when the novelty wears off, it wears off in a huge way. So, I can't really recommend the game in its current state - even as early access. My recommendation may change as the game develops, but this is very much pre-alpha stuff at the moment.

The game has potential (although, the dev's plans seem to go off the rails a bit... psychic abilities?!) So, it's best to wait and see to save yourself from disappointment.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is trash, I don't care that it is still in alpha. They give you no incentive to survive, no power boost, no levels, no scoreboard for time survived, nothing, just run around until you die, respawn, rinse and repeat. They shouldn't release a game in this condition. ESPECIALLY for the price of 17$! This and Early access are 2 very different things. I can name several Early access fresh release titles that were miles better than this game for around the same price (ARK and 2013 Rust) Maybe later in development the game will be better, but as it stands this game isn't worth its price. If you want a cool dinosaur game, go buy ARK survival. If you aren't a hardcore player go play on an unofficial server that has gather rate, xp, and taming turned up.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Absolutely nothing to do. The first game that after 30 minutes, got bored of, and immediately refunded it.

Pros
-Graphics

Cons
-Nothing to do other than eat, kill, and drink
-Everyone spawns in the same place
-Maps are boring
-Advertised single player, and there is no singleplayer (Well, kind of, it is just that there is no A.I., so unless you are a plant eater, its impossible)

I would not mind this, were it not for the fact that it is almost $20. I refunded this, and got other stuff well worth of my time. If you are needing to scratch a dinosaur itch, get Turok instead. Same price, and way better.

Final Score
2/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Speaking as someone who bought this game WITHOUT a pre-existing love for dinosaurs - it is still worth it. I was intrigued by the concept of being a dinosaur and their plans for the final product.  I wasn't sure how much fun the game would be in its current state but turns out it's a blast!

As-is, the game can get a bit tedious if you don't find somewhere to go or someone to fight. BUT that is just a result of the early access state and it is definitely fun in short sessions. The dinosaurs and environment are beautiful. The real joy though is experiencing hunting or being hunted, and forming packs or herds with other dinosaurs - especially when you're not the same species as you can only chat with your own kind and have to communicate through the in-game calls" or body language.

Bottom line - this game is worth it for the terror of hiding in a bush as a T-Rex stomps by looking for you and for the thrill of taking down your unsuspecting prey as they dopily frolick about."

I've had The Isle game for a while now and haven't been able to play as much as I'd love to due to school, family and commissions (ugh respoNsiIBILitiES). However, I have played it enough to know for certain that I love this game so much that if I didn't have crap to do then I'd most likely be on this game a lot more than I am now. This is a pretty neat MMORPG and I'd recommend it to any of my Dino loving friends out there.

Whenever I grab the opportunity to play The Isle, I'd be sat and playing on it for as long as possible. Sometimes it can just get quite addictive which would just lead to me being on it even longer due to me not keeping a very good watch on time. The Isle is all that a Dinosaur lover/RPer/Nature lover could possibly want in a game. The one thing I really love about this game is the regular updates and the fact that the creators actually stream their progress with the game itself. I love the textures, the objects, the shading and all the graphic jazz-- It's all eye candy.

Nothing really bad I can say about the game right now as it is only in Alpha version, so it's going to have a lot of work done to it. All I can really say is stay out of people's business as they can get pretty crabby.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is a game where you are able to play as a dinosaur, and humans will be added soon, so don't get your gun-holsters or whatever in a twist. This is an ultra-realistic game, and everything is very accurate, including the dinosaurs themselves, and the world. You can even break your leg, which becomes very annoying after a while. Unfortunatley there are a few flaws which kind-of break emmersion/the game itself. Number one and probably the most noticable to new players who have experience with literally any other game which allows you to interact with things (by pressing E), you are unable to eat anything BUT trees. As a smaller dinosaur such as a dryosaurus, or literally anything other than a puertasaurus (The game's currently only sauropod). The next issue is the fact that you may or may not be able to limp or feign limp on water. Another HUGE issue is with sounds. On a lot of dinosaurs, there are one or more calls which do not emit any sound when activated. This may be due to the recent additions of sound settings, but even with the highest sound quality, mainly the 'friendly' (num-bar 2) call and the Generic Roar (f) have been disfunctional for several different creatures. What I think may fix it is either removing the sound quality settings altogether OR making the Epic setting allow and encompass ALL sounds in-game instead of just most of them, which is what I think could be the issue. Another issue involving sounds are the fact that some dinosaurs have the wrong death sounds. For instance, when I am damaged or die as a gallimimus, for some reason I will sound like a carnotaurus. But enough of THAT rant, I am aware this is early access after all. This is overall a good game with  a lot of potential, and I hope this goes on to become a game which could be left to never update again, yet the community would be completely fine with the decision because the game is so polished. A good thing about the game is the growing variety of dinosaurs to play as and the imminent addition of pterosaurs, and eventually aquatic reptiles. Those are just the confirmed ones, what if there will be prehistoric mammals such as Gigantopithicus or Wooly Rhinocerous in the future? Maybe there will be mammal-like reptiles from before the dinosaurs, and maybe even the ancient, HUGE insects such as arthropleaura and meganeura? Titanboa is confirmed, so really the possibilities are endless. Well, maybe they have an end, but there's a heck of a lot of prehistoric creatures. And there's something about making herds in this game that just pumps you up, and the fact that it's so dangerous even for big herds is really cool. Other players definatley are the biggest risk to you, but as long as you have a big enough herd and a fit dinosaur, you'll probably be fine. Humans will add even more to the mayhem. Just imagine, your herd of shantungasaurus is about to fight a pack of t-rex in a clearing. Suddenly a band of hunters walks in on the scene, and suddenly it's a 3-way battle of life and dinner. The scene I have just described will only be even more epic with time and with the end of the game's beta.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you are the kind of person who has been searching for a DECENT survival game where you play as the dinosaur, this game is perfect. Yes, the game is early access, and some bugs still remain, but updates are so frequent that You could turn on the computer every day and expect one to be there. The game has many dino choices big and small, carnivore and herbivore. there are no omnivores yet, but I believe the devs will make one.
The game includes massive maps with realistic environments, and detailed, realistic models. You need to hunt to survive as a predator, and you also need to find water. Some people decide to 'carebear' and take care of the enemy species. For example, A T-rex will protect a Shantungosaurus from a pack of starving raptors. Realistic, huh. If you see those people just kill them. it will make you feel good.
I reccomend this game because it is already better than ARK: Survival Evolved. TheIsle isn't even completed yet, though it feels like a solid, complete game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Okay, this game is AMAZING, me myself who loves dinosaurs, knowing it's hard to come by an open world dinosaur survival game.  Most dinosaur games are you play as human or you play as dino, and this game will have both!  Animations are awesome graphics can be a pain if you don't have a good computer but, high graphics are awesome.

This has been said many times over and over again the devs take crap they don't deserve for things, the comunity is terrible to the devs, constantly asking for quetzal and release dates for updates but this has been done with quetzal, they said it was delayed for seven months, like right before I got the game.  This didn't make me that mad untill I saw everybody posting things about adding quetzal, that made me question it but then it got annoying because of TOO many pepole asking for it. And BTW release dates would NOT work with this comunity,

Now on to the gameplay!  The combat needs more work but it's an early access game so most of theese problems with be fixed so no worries.  So what I mean by the combat being a little lack luster right now is no collision (this will be added) the was that blood always comes out of the same spot for every dinosaur making it look like it comes out of the air (this will probally be fixed) so yeah most of everything that I do not like about the combat will probally be fixed.  But there is one thing I'm not sure about that thing is if sombody is in a pack or herd with you they should NOT be able to hurt you, because imagine you are a rex with 7 other rex's you come by a herd of 8 trike's you lose because someone in your pack hits you (not meaning too) this should also be added because of pepole betraying you, imagine your a shantu and you have a HUGE herd and somebody in the herd starts attacking pepole.  This would force a player to be in a herd or pack with pepole around it.

I do recomend this game to everybody who likes dinosaurs and to other pepole of different groups.  It's a overall fun game with lots of realistic things like the most accurate T-rex I've ever seen in my like (yes I know that's somping land's model) but still the other dinosaurs are accurate too like, carno, therizino, gally, austro, shantu, and many others.  One other thing I have said before is there needs to be a back kick for larger dinosaurs with mouse 3 and for peurta (since it already has a back kick) it should have a choice between tail whip and back kick.  Back kick RMB (or right mouse button) and tail whip should be mouse 3 (scroll) and the peurtas stomb attack with LMB (left mouse button) should be somewhat faster so pepole can still doge it but not so easy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a beyond amazing dinosaur survival game, going above and beyond in realism and texturing.

If your looking for a realistic dinosaur game, this is just about as good as you're going to get, but please understand that this game is early access and that it needs some serious work before the full game can really be experienced. The problems I've ran into is the OP dinosaur attacks and lack of need to survive besides the dangers of other dinosaurs hunting you. The Therizinosaurus needs work, its main attack being able to 1-shot even a T-rex, it can be annoying when your simply chilling with friendlies at the main pond and a stray ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ comes and screws it up because not only does he have the most damaging attack, but he can come back within minutes by getting a nearby spawnpoint with a fully grown dinosaur ready to kill. Not only that, but the smaller dinosaurs although not being OP can be annoying as ♥♥♥♥ when your playing a dinosaur with a short turning speed simply because they can always be at the back end of you and continue to bite you for a minute untill you bleed out because you cant get them. All in all, its an amazing game even at this state, and even though with some serious considderation as if the price tag is worth it at this time, you should definantly, without a doubt buy this when its on sale or not.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is a good game, love the idea. You play as a dinosaur in a survival" setting
date: living the day to day life of a dino. They have a decent ammount of dinos in the game right now but it seems everyone only plays Rexes
recommended: seeing how they are the top of the food chain more or less. You spawn into the map at a randomly generated spawn point and work your way towards water and food. reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is my first review for anything on steam. and this game is worthy of me giving the effort. When I bought this game. I could not stop playing. And now it's like 5 days later and I have 35 hours on it.
It's by far one of the best I have played and it's still early access.

What I enjoy about the game:
- massive open world
-impressive looking graphics and landscapes
- the brotherhoods that are born while playing as herbivores. You see one, your instantly friends so that you can survive long enough to fill your belly.
- the overall atmosphere of the game.
- the perilous journeys you have to embark on to find other herds or your food if a carnivore.
- the fact that you don't get a map.....because you are a dinosaur and have no use for one. You have to navigate by landmarks and general direction, adds some butt puckering moments when your walking through a forest and come across a pack of t rexes and your all by your lonesome.
- this is similar to gta online except with dinosaurs. And way better too.

Things I dislike about the game:
- the only real problem I have with it are the servers, but I know these will be tended to as it's still early access.

Overall. This game is amazing. It's truly cut from its own cloth, i recommend buying it. You will not be disappointed, you may be a little lost when you first start as I was, but keep figuring it out and you will have experiences that make you feel as if you are a dinosaur in that ancient hostile world.

The dinos look beautiful but...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really like the game but one of the recent updates has kind of ruined it.
Let me explain: I love how this is a survival game where you play as dinosaurs (both herbivores and carnivores), the community seems not too bad for as little as I've actually interacted with it and the gameplay is decent for now.
Though it has some very big issues in my opinion that make it almost unplayable for me.
The biggest one is them recently adding fall damage but it's not just that, it's very badly implemented: it happens when you fall one foot from the ground and it doesn't just do damage, it breaks your legs and forces you to move slower than normally walking all the time. A big issue with this is that you can't heal from it (or, if you can, it takes more than the 10 minutes I  had the patience to wait).
Another one of the bigger problems is not being able to change dinosaur whenever you want, the option to do so is just not there and I don't understand why. The only way to change dino is when you die and, since they made a 15 minutes suicide cooldown, when you  break your legs you have to end up waiting before changing dinosaur. They also made the mistake to not kill your character when you log off so now if you wanted to change character by logging back in, you're just gonna find your dino with broken legs and the 15 minute cooldown start over. This last thing is also very stupid because there's no progression so killing the dino literally made no changes.

So yeah, I can't really recommend playing it (especially for 20$), it was better before the recent updates.
voteText: 6 of 13 people (46%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have to edit this review.  I had initially reviewed as negative because of the bordum.  I have since put a lot more time into the game, and I have been on some fun servers.  However, most of the time I spawn on the other side of the map from the normal spawn, so most of my time is spent traveling, VERY SLOWLY, to where everyone else is.  It takes over two hours sometimes to make it carefully to other players, and if I break a leg (that happens a LOT!) then it takes even longer.

It is just not worth the time traveling because the play value of the actual combat, it's just not worth it.  The game suffers from being an arena game in an arena so massive that it can take half a day to accomplish anything, and there is nothing really to accomplish because there is no leveling, no skill tree, when you die you just restart with no loss of anything.  There is no XP gain, the only thing you really lose is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of time.  And you will lose a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of time no matter what you do!

This game is very very very early development, and I hope this isn't all they plan to incorporate into the game, because it will most definitely fail.  I think they plan on having humans, clans, etc. so there is still hope.

As for now, I don't recommend the game unless you just love the concept because the game is very slow to introduce new features, and there is no clear picture on where it will go at this time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Isle is very early access, but as the game sits now I wouldn't waste my money on it.

The devs need to get their fingers out of their noses and start making a GAME that's NOT Unreal Tournament Deathmatch with Dinos.

There's really nothing else to do on this program (as it's not even a game yet) but turn on each other in some Gladiator style fight to the death and all they're concerned about right now is putting in more machines of destruction than the story and/or progression or death penalties.

Go play 7 Days to Die. Go play Slime Rancher. Go play ARK. At least in those games, you can actually play a game and not some glorified multiplayer social platform with moving avatars and people ruining it with roleplaying. If I wanted that, I'd play Second Life.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe concept of this game is really fun, and its executed pretty well but there are too many flaws that make this game really boring and unfun, the maps are too large for the amount of players in each  server. You rarely encounter other players unless you spawn in a populated area and the combat is rather rough and I often found myself unable to hit people who were attacking me. The stamina system makes getting around the map even more tedious so if you spawn far away from anybody then you'll find yourself constantly running out of stamina and having to rest for like 3 minutes. The game has soooo much potential to be really fun and it IS but the map really needs an overhaul thats really my biggest complaint.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After 100 hours with the game, I think it's time I re-write my review.

DO NOTE: At this point the game is currently in 0.0.77, features are still incoming.

Summary
The Isle is a gritty open world survival game that pits humans versus some of the most impressive creatures to have ever walked the Earth, the Dinosaurs. Though currently in open access, the end result will see intense combat between the primal reptiles and the relatively new rulers of earth, and the inclusion of something in between...

Overview
The game is a lot of fun at first, however it loses it's luster, and numerous aspects of the game are working against it at the moment. It's an ambitious project however, and I hope it does well despite the challenges the developers, and to an extent us players, face as we push the game closer to official release.

Gameplay
At the moment the only mode is a free for all deathamatch, players can choose between multiple species, from classics like Triceratops, Stegosaurus, and Tyrannosaurus Rex to lesser known dinosaurs like Diabloceratops, Puertasaurus, and Austroraptor. Each dinosaur plays a little differently, and it shows in how the players use them. Once you spawn in the biggest concern is finding food and water, and depending on the animal, sometimes another player is your food, or you might just be on the menu yourself. The dinosaurs all work well together, however the game is not totally balanced yet, as the devs are planning on adding more dinosaurs and other features before getting down to the grit. There are some issues with this, me personally have found that raptor players are able to exploit the turn radii of larger dinosaurs and pretty much just bite you in the ♥♥♥ to death, and you can't do anything about it. A raptor soloing a rex is not cool, and I'll specifically say this is my biggest gripe right now.

There is a chat function that is currently species specific. There is also a WIP groupiung system that currently has little benefit but knowing who you're playing with in your group. The chat can be rather annoying at times, and there can often be trolls or immature players in the chat. People seem to get the idea it's a dinosaur chatroom simulator.

There's not much to the gameplay, and this combined with there often not being full servers can lead to very boring games where you are better off studying the map than trying to interact with other species. But as a survival game this is how they all are.

Aesthetics
I play on a rather low gaming quality PC, so I can't testify to ultra settings, but I can tell you how well the game runs on low, haha.

The sounds are great, the devs took a note from Jurassic Park, and molded together the animal sounds from existing animals to create unique vocals for the dinosaurs. They Tyrannosaurus has an intimidating roar, that while is not a ferocious bellow, heralds the arrival of the king of dinosaurs. The Puertasaurus practically sings as it plods it's way across the landscape, the songs of a moving herd are almost like music. The Austroraptor chirps rather ominously in the forest at night, and it'll make your eyes dart across the trees as you move from watering hole to watering hole.

The game does not play well on lower end machines. I actually go into the console and lower my field of view and disable grass in order to reach 60 fps at I believe 800 x 640, otherwise I get less than 30. It's only going to get worse before it gets better, so if you're not at a good spot with your machine, wait until the game drops to see if it's better optimized. The dinosaurs however look great, and I really do like looking at the models move around in the world with their crisp animations.

The menus are clear and easy to understand, and the in game HUD is very nice as well! Honestly there's very few ways to muff that up, so it's a good sign the devs can get that done, lol.

Community
Hoo boy here we go...

Some games just have communities that are great, some not so much. This is a not so much.

Despite the growing age of Dinosaur fans (I myself and 3 years younger than Jurassic Park, and I certainly would not have wanted my mom to let me participate in this game way back in, say, 2003 if it came out then,) The Isle's community is, well, kinda lackluster. There's a great deal of immaturity amongst the players, even myself sometimes. There's constant arguing over game mechanics, among other people constantly requesting that their favorite dinosaur be added. It's somewhat grating. There's also people who will either be quick to criticize, or quick to emptily compliment the developers. Often times in the hub it's a battle of who can write the most sarcastic reply, but that doesn't get anything done, and really actually puts me off. In a community based game that behavior is toxic and does no good.

The developers themselves, well, they're not my favorite developers ever. For an Early Access game where you have to work with your playerbase to see what works and what doesn't they don't seem to want to do much of that. Often times the devs have proven to be callous people, uninviting, rude, acidically sarcastic, and quick to throw out bans and respond to being called any of the former with throwing down the book. There's obviously a lack of professionalism in the dev team (No set dates for anything, not even estimates,) and they've made it hard to actually want this game to perform better than it's competition because they don't seem like people I really want to support, however I've played their game for 100 hours now and have decided it's for the best if we all try to make this project succeed. There has to be a compromise between both the community and the dev team in how they behave and interact both between each other and within each other.

Conclusion
So The Isle is currently a game that is really pulling along and trying to make itself as great as it can. This is crucially because of the interactions of the dev team, and the players giving it feedback.

This is a very strained relationship. Too much criticism and negativity will shut everything down, but too much complimenting and positivity won't critically look at the game and fix it.

But if you think you want this game, and you're reading this to see if you should jump in and get to playing, don't do it. A multiplayer game crucially needs the support of it's community, and the community is too infantile and snide to realize that hey, maybe if they weren't so rude to every person who has a criticism, idea, or isn't generally kissing the backside of the game and the devs, then perhaps more people would feel welcome and would participate. But no, it's a toxic and hostile environment, and you won't want to stay very long if you might think differently from the pack.

TL;DR
The community is ♥♥♥, don't join it. Because the game needs it's community to succeed, don't buy the game and support such ridiculously juvenile behavior. Support a different game like Dinosaur Battlegrounds or Saurian instead, this one suffers from being the edgy kid in class who likes to be a jerk to everybody, but still somehow has the audcatiy to complain about being lonely. If the competition were anywhere near the same stage, it would be easy to see the holes not in the game itself, but in the people holding the game up, who are just as much a part of the experience.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game features a few Progression-Stopper bugs (progressions stopper bugs are normally the WORST bugs you could encounter, they force you to restart your whole progress) that forces the user to Logout if he gets stuck in the environement, he falls throught the map or is glitched in Austroraptor (pressing jump and crouch at the same time locks your character and you cant do anything else but hover around).That wouldnt be so bad if the logout option wasnt glitched as well and crashes the game everytime you use it (this bug was in the game since day 1 of Early Access).

Bugs are to be expected in a Early access game but i would expect the devs to work on fixing those issues before introducing new features which isn't the case. Like Ark survival they are adding new features without fixing what is already there but unlike ARK this game is a shell of a game so it has no redeeming factor.

The content (basicly only models and animations at this point) is good... thats mainly because the models werent made by the devs they were made for another EA game that failed...

This is probably the devs first game but i see a grim future for it.

Edit March 3rd 2016: Since the time of review, some of the major bugs seem to have been fixed.(hard to play solo since you cant suicide to try the other dinosaurs) But on the other side the devs are lookin more and more like they hate their playerbase.And they deleted the whole sub-forum where people wrote bug reports for them for free, how nice...

TL/DR:
Dont support this game in Early access, if you like dinosaurs just buy Ark.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

[Early Access Review]
The Isle is your generic casual sandbox game that offers nothing new, implements nothing exciting and innovates in no fields to entertain player. This review is written by someone who wanted to like this game but only ended up forcing himself to play as much as he did despite being bored to the bone.

The game is about different species of dinosaurs surviving on a large island without any affect of mythical or modern day creatures. It is all about dinosaurs of different eras and that's something intriguing for players who are looking for something new, different.

However the application of game is just same as any other survival game you'll find. Vast empty sandbox island with dinosaurs who can do nothing, I mean they really can do nothing at all other then fighting each other. For me, this is not a survival game. This is counter strike with dinosaurs.

There are no npc creatures yet, that is planned to be implemented later but so far all dinosaurs are other players, and In the servers, even in those half full, you're lucky to meet anyone. Since you are all by yourself most of the time, what else is there to do? You can not dig dirt, collect bits and branches, build a nest or do what dinoes do. All there is to actually accomplish is run around and bite others.

Fighting is disgracing, so far only fighting option is run into someone and swing your weapon. That can be a tail a jaw or claws. Only raptors may have the option to cling on bigger dinosaurs and claw them but other then that it is boring, distasteful, and often awkwardly short. It doesn't feel like accomplishing anything. Just, boring.

The death has no penalty, making it useless to actually put any effort into survival. That also creates trolls who walk around to kill randomly without  provocation or any worthy intention. The death screen is awkward, it just pops up out of nowhere. In 2016 you can not see what happened, or what is going on afterwards. Sometimes you just want to watch how your pack progresses with current fight but no you can not. Not allowed.

The graphics used to be laggy, too much flexy grass causing stress on graphics card but that seems fixed now, it runs smoothly and the graphics are actually really good. Even thou the dino selection screen is made for ants, i mean the preview of dinosaurs is very very very tiny, you need a magnifier to see what it actually is; once you are in the game it is exciting. The animations are nice, thou they could've been better, for an mmo they're very smooth and well designed. The environment is okay, and other then certain few menues exceeding the screen width the game is graphically above average.

I wished to avoid making any positive or negative recommendation about the game for now but steam enforced me into doing so. I'll just hope there are still surprises in the developer's bag however till then there is nothing makes me want to play this game. Really, my score would be 3/10 for other players but for me it's 4/10 because i like dinosaurs after all.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe Isle is quite a fun game, when you're not running into packs of T.Rexes, that outnumber you 10-1. The graphics are nice, there's a much larger selection of dinosaurs than in other games of its type, the community is decent, the maps are huge, and the servers have plenty of spots. On top of this, the dev team is great. They're always very active, and they listen to the community. Bug fixes are frequent, and there isn't so many major patches that new content gets boring fast. I strongly reccomend The Isle to anyone who is a fan of prehistory; just remember, it's not a game that revolves around killing everyon you see.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm going to try and keep this review as unbiased as I can for those who want an honest interpretation of the game.

Do not jump into this game thinking that what you see, is what you get. This game is in early alpha and features are being added all the time. What is meta gameplay now, will not be the same in a few weeks. Species will be added, maps will change, and each new feature added will bring with it a whole new level of difficulty. If hardcore survival is not your thing, I'd turn away now because this game is only going to get harder as time goes on. And frankly, that's not a bad thing.
But it is something you'll need to understand before buying this game. Something which, apparently, a lot of people did not consider before buying and reviewing. This game was never mean to be easy, and you'll need to keep an open mind about it as it develops further. Bleeding, starvation, broken bones, and limping are all perfect examples of this. Each of these features added a whole new level of difficulty to the game and because of it, people were forced to adapt to different playstyles to survive. My point is if you can't adapt, don't purchase the game right now.

Humans will be added in the future, and this open world game is only going to get bigger. Imagine the Skyrim map, Final Fantasy open exploration, and the hardcore survival of Day-Z all combined into one.

PROSE:
Beautiful maps.
Great Models.
Smooth animations.
Clear sounds.
Plenty of players.
Constant Updates.
Vast open maps
Wide variety of characters. More coming soon
Hardcore Survival

CONS
In Alpha
Not fully optimised.
Descent PC needed to run.
Low server stability.
Very difficult to find your friends / navigate without prior knowledge

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When you get this make sure you play on the Region map and not Mesa. Mesa is too big without friends, takes around half an hour of aimless walking to just find one other person but Region is amazingly fun. If you play Mesa at first you won't enjoy it, I wouldn't have kept playing if I didn't know about Region

My second time coming on, started as a T-rex, was being nibbled on by a raptor, so I ran between a long necks legs and when he stomped for me just made it out, stomping the little raptor trying to eat my feet. We became friends and I encomponied him on a journey to the lake, meeting five other rex's on the way and a galli we were an unlikely herd. After fending off any predators and angry Shantus we finally made it to the lake. We had around ten minutes of playing, drinking and bathing before seven carnatours came, they encircled us slowly as we roared at them, and all at once they ran into us, a blood bath ensued with only one t rex surviving. I was that T rex. It was beautiful.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Isle is in Early Access, so of course there is a ton of bugs that can ruin or completely stop you from playing the game for a while, and that's just a risk you have to accept if you're buying the game.

A lot of people complain about the devs, and yes, they can be very rough and/or sarcastic at times, but it's mostly to people being rude, stupid or simply DEMANDING dinosaurs or features to be added or tweaked to whateverness (one person even went so far as to say he would kill Dondi, the main developer, if he didn't make the Quetzalcoatlus (a VERY overhyped pterosaur) public, even though it's a WIP, buggy as Hell and crashes servers left, right and center).
If you just don't annoy the devs, think about what you're about to say and try to find the answer in the unofficial guide which Karmataurus, a mod, made (it's pinned in a post on the discussions board), you're good to go. And please, for the love of everything holy, read and understand the Store page!

As for the game itself, it's coming along wonderfully, with regular updates, a new major addition every few weeks, and sudden bursts of bug fixes and reveals of WIP features and creatures.
I have no doubt in my mind that this game will be amazing when finished, but right now, in-game is just one big pile of T. rex (most of them being very immature people) and mindless killing at the most popular lake, Spawn Lake, where >80% of players go to. But progression will hopefully be in soon, which means people have to work hard to unlock bigger dinosaurs so that a rex isn't nearly as common a sight as it is now.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is very decent in my opinion. The graphics look utterly amazing when played at maximum settings, even at the lowest possible settings the game looks very good. The models of the dinosaurs are very scientifically accurate. The plethora of skins that are being offered caters to different playstyles (If you want to be flamboyant and look more dominant, there are more vivid coloring options, and if you want a more camoflauged look, there are skins that blend in with your enviornment.)
Sometimes the events in this game are amazing, and the best part is they're not even scripted. I remember finding a herd of two Diablos, and I'm perched behind two trees with the green camo on as a tyrannosaurus rex, and they didn't seem to notice me. I proceeded to slowly crawl towards them from the behind, where they did not see me, and I then proceeded to attack one of the diablos and killed it, while the other diabloceratops fled. There are some optimization issues, but that is to be expected for it is an Early Access video game, and I'm sure the developers are working on improving it.
I enjoy the concept of the game, and the fact that the game isn't even near completion and it's already amazing makes me like this game even more. The fact that they will add humans and tribes, cannibals, new dinosaurs, strains, etc... makes the game look very promising. I definitely recommend this game to any dinosaur enthusiast, and any person who simply wants to have fun with a game.
Sure there have been problems with moderators and devs and whatnot, but most of the problems with the developers have already been resolved. This is meant to be a game review, regardless, not a developer review, something most people seem to ignore.

If you do decide to purchase this game, then have a great adventure!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As of late 12/2015 the game is pretty rough and basic. A handfull of very colorful dinosaurs to choose from and a vast island to roam. The chat system and overall interface is rudimentary at best right now and at times lag can be an issue.

Now with all that on the table, it has been a TON of fun so far. The community that has so far adopted the game have been pretty rewarding. People travel in packs of Herbivores vs Carnivores and with very little meat to the gameplay have created a very entertaining experience.

If nothing else you might consider picking this one up to support the team and to sit on this egg until it hatches.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am going to give this a recommend out of the potential this game could be.

First, just an introduction.  I like dinosaurs, you can see it in the games I have.  I like them, but not enough to where they are integral to a game.  I'm giving this game a reccomend as out of the survival games I have played this is a FIRST FOR ME where you are put in a different sort of playstyle in a survival game.
Think about it.  Nearly all the games I have seen on Steam is where you go around gather this, to craft this, to build this.  Over and over again.  Sure, Ark spiced the flavour up a bit with taming but still.  This game gives you a new playstyle.

Think of this as  an Alien vs. Predator game meets Ark.  Your dinosaurs are like the Aliens.  You go around killing things to get stronger or to build a herd.
Then you have the Cannibals which are like Predators.  You leap from tree to tree, kill dinosaurs, tame dinosaurs (in a brutal fashion), and eat the human players.
Last but not least, the humans are like the USCM.  You survive, find guns, then kill the other dinosaur/cannibal players.

Now, the cannibals/humans are of course not added yet.  But the potential this game could have with all three thrown into a mix would make for an interesting game.

As of right now, it's severely lacking in content.  There isn't much risk/reward right now.  But the game is getting updated steadily.  I wouldn't neccesarily suggest buying the game right now.  Maybe when they have added 1 of the 2 other classes. Right now though, the game has promise and I hope to see it succeed.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI love dinosaurs and i have wanted to play this game for a long time. I don't have a PC, i play the game on mac. I recently downloaded the game on my mac and launched it. I joined a small server so i could learn the controls without getting killed. But the texture for the land didn't load in. It was white and grey tiles and it really bothered me. The mountains and clearings looked weird due to this. Then it lagged really bad. (probably because of my internet) I quit and joined 30 mins later and the texture still didn't load in, but grass trees, and so on did. There was no longer any lag just the texture problem. I tried to join a popular server so i could properly play. It loaded for about 3 minutes then the game froze completely in the loading screen. I had to manually restart my computer and it then it said that the Isle was unresponsive. Once i restarted i tried to join servers like Atlanta, Germany, Chichago, New york, and some others... The same thing happened everytime. I could only join servers that had about five people on it :/ I met up with about 4 people on  a small server and every one was lagging alot again. Then the latest patch came out. I tried to join servers but it said my game was out of date and to restart Steam and update. But i did everything and it never updated. I restarted Steam at least 5 times. I changed the update systems to every possible option, then restarted. I forced the game to search for updates by right clicking the isle and doing that thing in the options in local files. I restarted my computer and everything. I know this game is in early devolpement and all but i really want to be able to play the game normally just like everyone else. I don't know why it's doing this so can you guys fix the mac build and tell me what's wrong? until then i will keep trying...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great game, awesome graphics and high FPS (even if optimization isn't at its best, not to mention I have a rather bulky computer) and diligent devs working constantly on the game. On Thursday alone there were at least 3 patches! Kudos to you, devs.

However, every game has its flaws. The broken-leg mechanic is kind of janky; you can trip over a patch of pebbles and break something, then be forced to wait fifteen to thirty minutes (if your food and water are over 80) for it to heal. Maybe increase the distance you have to fall a bit more, so this doesnt happen? It'd be great!

Another thing to note is the consistent connection losses or crashes. I understand that not all hosts are perfect, or games for that matter, but.. one of the other happens every half-hour or so. Gets irritating after a while.

All in all, though, I recommend it to anyone looking forward to buying The Isle, or any dinosaur lovers! Very fun if you have a decent computer, and even if flawed, worth your money.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is very fun! It IS an early access Alpha stage game, so not much of it's real content is in the game. If you aren't willing to take the risk, or aren't patient (Two different things!) then don't buy this game yet. (YET) To the rest of you I will list the pros and cons I've come across:

Pros:
- Fun game, just like, in general.
- Fun people. It's a decent community, given it is the internet.
- Beautiful. The game just looks good. The graphics are nice, the dinos look amazing, it's just splended.
- YOU GET TO BE A DINO! C'mon!
- The Devs actually TALK to you! You want to give feedback which isn't whining and B****ing? They will listen to you then!
- Updates, patches and such are very common. There have been a few days (Since I've aquired the game) at which there were 2 patches, these Devs are hard working.

Cons:
-It's only alpha, with very little actual game content in it. (I already said that, but incase you sped read past it, and don't have working eyeballs there it is again)
-The dinos need some more balancing (They have been working on it, it's getting there)
-Occasional lag, or lots of it if you don't turn your graphics down (even for a good computer.)

All in all this game is amazing. I'm excited to see where the Devs take it, and I am thrilled to be a part of this community and watching this game change almost daily. I can't wait to see the end product, and best of all, play it! If you have any questions, please feel free to ask! :D
